reviewText:
Notable features:
Infinite combo prevention system (so combos are more complex and ironically less escapable)
Asshats on motorcycles
Strong female characters (if you're into that)
Sexually suggestive clothing (if you're into that)
A whopping eight people to play online with
Controller support
A boat made entirely out of blood
You may have heard there is glorious anime cleavage in this game. You have not been misinformed. Just go ahead and buy it now if that's what you're here for. I'll be here, making disapproving faces at my computer and pretending you can see me.

I've been told Skullgirls is one of the most technical fighting games to exist. A goodly few of the mechanics were designed in part by fighter champion Mike Mike Z" Zaimont. As a salty casual who can't beat the tutorial but still makes a ham-fisted attempt at playing anyway
date: I know I've only scratched the surface of what can be done with this game (a process akin to scratching the surface of the moon). I've seen videos of high-level play
recommended: and it is astonishing. So if you're somebody who can decipher the phrase "qc.P+P -> a.HK -> dp" you'll find a lot to love here. If you can't
hoursPlayed: that's no reason not to buy this game. The combat is fun and engaging even if you can't explain to your friends what's happening in absurdly small acronyms.\n\nSkullgirls has 13 playable characters
voteText: each with their own engrossing story modes and unique playstyles (up from 9 in the wake of a devastatingly successful Indiegogo campaign). At least 2 more characters are still on the way. If you grab them fresh out of the oven

reviewText:
Review For Skullgirls PC Review by : Panda Waifu & Meguca 2.0

Pros : - Great animations
- Incredible artstyle
- Lovely music
- Very good value for the money
- Mechanically impressive

Cons : - Weak keyboard controls (Gamepad recommended)
- Multiplayer is unforgiving for newcomers
- Really hard to master

Review :Skullgirls is a game full of things to love, which can all be appreciated on their own, which all come together to make a unique experience.

First, the visuals:
Skullgirls is easily one of the most visually impressive games you'll ever play. Every single animation is drawn in incredible detail, everything looking extremely smooth and natural. It is worth playing almost for the visuals alone.

Next, the controls: Keyboard controls are done well, but a controller is highly recommended for anyone who wants to fully explore this game, and the abundant movelists, combos, and other features. The tutorials are also far better suited for preparing a player using a controller, rather than a keyboard.

If you're a veteran at fighting games, you'll be pleased at how 'technically' impressive Skullgirls is, allowing for a ton of ways to chain attacks, get massive combos and feel in control. Players who are newer to fighters don't have to worry, there is a tutorial covering a massive amount of game mechanics, and the movelists are easy to understand. As always with fighter games, it can be quite relentless to try and get to high skill levels and pull off every move and mechanic with ease, it does take a lot of practice.

For casual players and veterans alike, there's a ton to enjoy. Story mode covers a pretty cool plot, each character's story really helps to flesh them out and make them feel a bit more alive. You fight your way through a series of matches, a few adding a bit to the story through pre-fight dialog, until you reach a pretty challening final boss where you conclude that character's story. There is a variety of difficulty options available, making it accessible to both beginner and hardcore players.

The character roster is relatively limited, with 8 Fighters being available in the base game, and 4 added DLC fighters (and a Hidden one) available through DLC. It is worth mentioning that if you own the base game upon a DLC's release, it is available for free for a significantly long time. Otherwise, you have to buy the DLCs separately. This can be quite a turn-off for some players, but given the depth of each character it is more than enough to get a ton of enjoyment out of Skullgirls.

Gameplay wise, every character has a variety of moves. There are light, medium and heavy punches and kicks (varying in range, damage, speed, etc on each character) as well as specials, crouched attacks, jumping attacks, and all the other things common to all fighters. Every character has varying difficulties, making them better or worse for less skilled players. A newcomer can likely buttonmash their way through a few PVP matches or the story mode, but on higher difficulties or vs someone who is skilled at fighters will be a brick wall to that strategy.

For many players, the multiplayer is the most important part. From a technical standpoint, the multiplayer was done well and can provide a lag-free environment to anyone who wants to get into it. The community isn't HUGE, but there's always players to face, but as a word of warning, most players you encounter online are very skilled. It can be near impossible to get into as a newcomer to fighters or to Skullgirls. For this reason I do recommend playing this game locally if possible.

In conclusion :Every moment is enjoyable with the beautiful animation and artstyle, there's a challenge to be found if you're looking for one, and there's a casual, enjoyable experience for those who just want to appreciate the art, voice acting and story.
And for those reaons I'm giving this game a recommendation!

Platforms : PC, Xbox360, Playstation 3.
Developer: Lab Zero Games.
Genre: Action, Indie
Publisher: MarvelousAQL.
Release Date: 22 Aug, 2013.
Website : http://skullgirls.com/

Follow my Curator page : http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/
Always do more research than just reading a review, to ensure that you get the right product.
Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
It's a very solid fighting game, it's not 3rd strike or Tekken 3 or another fighting game with 3 in title but it's good nonetheless, and here's why.

Character roster is not robust but it still covers a variety of playstyles, all rounders, zoners, grapplers and speed characters... To put it shortly, despite the lack in numbers every character feels different from one another.

This game has best tutorial I've ever seen in a fighting game. It doesn't just show you which buttons do what, this tutorial will explain you every little thing about how this game works and how each character plays and when you're done, there's still a lot of space for creativity and improvement.

Story mode is... fine. I'm honestly not a big fan of it, story itself is quite predictable and largely based on one or two standard tropes that many fighting games use. Final boss felt a bit disappointing for me but it's kind of a hit or miss situation. Some will like that there's a special character that is very different from anyone else in a very fundamental way but I personally prefer when at the end you face just a character from the roster like everyone else you've been fighting before. Also at the time I was beating the game it seemed like the only way to beat the boss on higher difficulties was to just cheese her out and that's not really fun in my opinion but it was some time ago and by now people probably got much better at the game and found out other, more interesting ways to beat the boss.

Multiplayer... I wish I could say something about it but I only managed to play it once with some guy from Australia (and I live on the edge between Europe and Asia) with both of us having ping over 150 or something like that... not exactly enjoyable expirience (though i have to say lag compensation was rather nice even in that dire situation) but it was the only expirience avaliable at the time. I recommend you check out something like steam charts if you buy this game for multiplayer, and check if you have some sort of community for this game in your area.

Visuals and sound are very good. Background music is not distracting and yet very charming, reminds me of something Yoko Kanno would've composed but it still sound quite unique and recognisable. Animation and art is beautiful and smooth, yeah there are boobs and butts but they offend as much as Switzerland. There are plently of stages and all of them look amazing. Game looks and sounds very good, period.

And to finish it off, gameplay and controls. They are both very, very solid. I use a fight stick and it works like a charm, as it should,  obviously. Keyboard is also fine though, it's much harder for me to play on keyboard, but I don't see why you wouldn't be able to get good results with it after some practice, though I have to say fight stick is real sweet. Game mechanics are way beyond what you would expect from an indie dev, gameplay feels very polished and refined, every time I lost I knew that it was my fault and what that fault was and that's a big deal in any game.

So yeah, this game is good, I liked it, pros overwhelm cons and I wish this game sells even better so there would be more people to play with.

reviewText:
Every now and then, a game comes along that truly deserves to be called capital-g Great. I don’t mean a game that’s merely fun, or entertaining, or even aesthetically beautiful – all great things, but no single aspect of which would nudge a title beyond the level of “good”. I’m talking about a game that manages to mix a creative, imaginative world filled with original, memorable characters, equipped with polished gameplay, and to pull it all off with an expert craftsman’s level of skill and attention to detail – including literally thousands of frames of character animation. Skullgirls is a traditional close-combat fighting game that manages to bring all of this to the table. If you are a fan of 2D fighting games who has yet to add Skullgirls to your library, you owe it to yourself to rectify this situation as soon as possible. It would be a deal at twice the price.

Now, I’ve enjoyed fighting games since the days of King of Fighters and Street Fighter II – but outside of casually decking friends in Soul Calibur, the fact is I’ve never been particularly enamored with the genre for the gameplay’s sake, or even very good at the games. What’s always drawn me in, believe it or not, is the story and the personalities. Sure, the actual plots are typically paper-thin, cotton candy fluff – the Heihachi family’s internal squabbles in Tekken, the Orochi power in King of Fighters… it’s all silly stuff even (perhaps especially) when it tries to be serious, and it mostly serves as a backdrop to create fun, creative characters and personalities.

The setting of Skullgirls stands out even alongside the crazier, Guilty Gear variety of bizarre worlds, setting itself in the fictional Canopy Kingdom – a cartoony environment most reminiscent of the art deco designed 1940s, dominated by crime, strange creatures, and hybrids of technology and magic. Even before you get to the actual character storylines in Skullgirls, the visuals it presents you with – a mix of black, gold, neon and film reel decorations – is enough to make it incredibly distinct, as if someone took the setting of the original Bioshock and decided to make it all ten times more cartoony, and about a quarter as serious.

As for the plot itself, Skullgirls provides a situation reminiscent of most fighting game contexts: every seven years, a living artifact known as the Skull Heart offers to grant the wish of one woman. But if the wisher has an impure soul, she’ll instead be transformed into a powerful, monstrous Skullgirl – leading her to terrorize and wreak havoc over the world. A young girl named Marie has made her wish and apparently been found unworthy, leading various characters to set their sights on her, each with their own motives – some seeking to simply bring her assault to an end, while others are after the power of the Skull Heart for themselves. In Story mode, you’ll select one of these eight characters (with five more either available or on the way via DLC) and follow their journey, learning about their histories and their motivations along the way via beautifully drawn cutscenes and dialogue – but mostly, you’ll spend your time kicking ♥♥♥ in straight up frantic combo-chaining, guard-breaking style.

But before you even throw punch one, you’d do well to encounter the first feature that really makes Skullgirls shine – the tutorial mode. While it may sound odd to heap praise on what sounds like the most bog-standard addition to any game, let me emphasize: what sets Skullgirls apart on this front is the sheer depth of the tutorials. Let’s face it – fighting games are complicated, and despite having played many of them for so many years, I’d be lying if said I understood half of the fundamental mechanics that were at work in more serious matches. Here, things are different. Rather than simply cutting the player loose to understand the mechanics of the game on their own, or hunt details up online, the tutorials walk you through everything from the most basic low-medium-high punch/kink button layout, right down to throws, combo chaining, cancels, and even the ins and outs of each of the individual characters’ styles and moves.

But what really makes Skullgirls shine above all else is the sheer effort that has gone into the polishing of all of its audio-visual aspects. The soundtrack is actually something to stand up and take notice of, being a collection of largely-jazzy tunes that do a good job of fitting the fantasy-1940s setting of the Canopy Kingdom. Character voices are crisp, clear and distinctive, adding a whole lot of personality to the Skullgirls themselves. But it’s the art and animation that is truly breath-taking, in more ways than one.

So here’s where we’re at when all is said and done: a fighting game set in a gloriously original world, racked out with unique characters whose hand drawn animations are stunningly detailed and comprehensive. The soundtrack of the game is – at least for jazz fans – beautiful enough to warrant an OST purchase all on its own. The graphical presentation is phenomenal, the story mode is entertaining, the characters are unique and engaging as a whole. There’s a comprehensive in-game tutorial available for the game’s mechanics in general, and each character in particular. There’s DLC coming, there’s online and local matchups available, there are achievements and alt colors to unlock… and on top of all of this, the whole package is available for $14.99, or even less if you buy a multi-pack with a friend or three.

The only real downsides to speak of is some highlights of sex appeal that may turn off some players, the frank necessity to own a controller to truly enjoy the game, and the fierce competition players will face in online versus play. Those are some incredible positives, and very forgivable negatives.

As it stands, this very likely is the best PC fighting game available, period – and doubly so for the money. And not only that, but buying the game gives you access to the Skullgirls Beta, so you can test out changes in advance of their going live in the game proper. If you’re a fighting game fan, what more do you want?

reviewText:
I've been beaten senselessly by half the characters on normal or higher.
The boss has wiped the floor with me more times than I can count.
I can barely pull off 15 hit combos while the AI can seamlessly pull off 30-hit comboes ending in a Blockbuster every other attack.

And yet I still keep coming back to this game.
Why, you ask?
Simply because it's the greatest fighter game I've ever played.
You will find yourself playing this game over and over with its easy to learn, difficult to master playstyle, with anything from a ridiculously easy Sleepwalk mode for the starters to a downright nasty Nightmare mode for those who know what they're doing and do it well.
You will fall in love with the playstyles of each and every one of these characters, from Filia, the girl with a fanged monster for hair, to Peacock, the living cartoon character, to Ms. Fortune, the zombie catgirl who can decapitate herself at will, and everyone in between.
You will find yourself in awe at the amazing background scenery and music of every last stage, from Maplecrest's calming The Lives We Left Behind" to the techno beats of Lab 8's "Paved With Good Intentions" to the rocking jazz of Under the Bridge's "Unfinished Business".
You will laugh at every single one of these characters' lines

recommended: to Ms. Fortune's terrible as crud puns

reviewText:
IT'S NOT MARVEL, IT'S NOT CAPCOM.

IT'S NOT GUILTY, NOR IS IT BLUE.

HOLY MOTHER OF GOD! IT'S SKULLGIRLS ON STEAM!

This game is amazing, It takes everything that's great about The Marvel vs Capcom games and ArcSystem Works games. Whether 1v1, or 2v1 or 3v3, etc. The Possible Match outcomes for this game are plenty.

The Game also has a nice sizable cast even without the DLC updates and sometimes a small cast can help you out in the long run, but that's not to say the DLC characters aren't anything to miss because when you play this game, more than likely you're gonna play with the full roster.

But the main reason why you should get this game is because it's SUPER USER FRIENDLY with it's in depth tutorial mode. Yes that's right, not only does this game have a Story/Arcade mode and Multiplayer (local and online), This game has a mode dedicated to teach you how to play fighting games. Yeah you read that right IT TEACHES YOU HOW TO PLAY FIGHTING GAMES. Not just Skullgirls, but it does help there too. The Game actually teaches you about Hitboxes and Recoveries and Punishes and all of that stuff you hear at EVO live streams, it's freakin' great!

And after done with the Tutorial you'll have a better understanding on how this game is played and how all other fighting games are played so it's a win win.

This is the perfect Fighting game for beginners and the Communtiy is well too So if you were ever interested in the genre this is a good place to start.

5/5 stars!

reviewText:
Very polished and aesthetically pleasing // A must have for 2D fighter enthusiasts
+ Fluid and well-rendered animations
+ Environmental designs are absolutely gorgeous, particularly for a 2D fighter
+ Voiceovers are excellent, and every line serves well to increase the game's appeal
+ Soundtrack and general audio design are well above-par
+ One can choose custom assists that look and feel great, and add significantly to an already ample pallet of possible attack combinations
+ Each fighter feels absolutely and wholly unique
+ Online functionality runs smoothly, with minimal delay or performance impact
+ Solid, classic, and superbly well-rounded fighter mechanics
+ Competent tutorial mode is more than adequate to acclimate new players

- Limited unlockables and gameplay modes
- Short story modes, even for a fighter
- Small pool of playable characters, even taking DLC into consideration

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

this is a satire review, im not actually a christian mom. im some nerd who plays vidya gaims. serious review below

First Impressions
So I've never played a fighting game that uses 6 buttons and a stick (I don't know what that's called) or any fighting game so I was going into Skullgirls blind. I didn't have any interest in this game or genre before I saw my friends playing it. I was facisnated by the animations, graphics, and how smooth it looked. The first time I played it I chose Valentine and mashed buttons on a PS3 controller not caring for blockbusters, blocking, or combos; I was having too much fun even without knowing a lot of the game's functions.

Gameplay
As I mentioned before, I don't own a controller or 6 button gamepad, so I play with a keyboard.
While the game may play a lot better on a controller, I found it very easy to play with a keyboard. The learning curve isn't that hard making it very easy for a newbie like me to get into. Any newcomers to a fighting game scene could learn how to play this game very easily, every move and blockbuster is just as easy to do on a keyboard as it is as controller. Skullgirls doesn't have a lot of characters to choose from, but all of those characters have unique playstyles that can go from fast light-hitting, quick aerial combat, to slow but powerful heavy-damaging. But all characters have light, medium, and heavy attacks but some characters are more attuned to a certain playstyle. And every character has unique blockbusters that can turn the tides of a fight when used properly along with combos. Combos can go on for quite some time, but they aren't infinite. Infinity breakers come in to play from what I could tell when the combo gets sloppy or slows down, giving you time to breath. Blocking, parrying, grabbing, armor, etc. are all also in the game can be used to your advantage but can be countered to an extent. Overall the game has very solid gameplay and I would recommened it to both newcomers and veterans to this genre.

Graphics
The game looks great with an anime-esque draw style where every frame is edited perfectly to make it look as smooth as possible. The game also runs great, there's no drops in framerate anywhere to be seen and it looks amazing. All the characters look great, in both a sexy and badass way. The designs of the characters influence how they fight and look. Filia has a parasite on her head (Samson) and uses him as a way of combat. Big Band uses a variety of instruments, Valentine a bunch of medical things, and etc. It's worth playing a character just for their aesthetic. it's also nice to look at their boobs

Overall
The game is great, it's a solid fighting game with a great diverse cast that can do different things. The addition of more characters is really great. The price tag of 15 bucks is really fair and on sale it's a must buy. Anyone can get into this game no matter how they view the genre. Skullgirls is an amazing game, and you should get it and play it.

This is a really fun game, and an extensive tutorial will welcome beginners smoothly even though I can't ♥♥♥♥ing beat it GODAMNIT I CAN'T ♥♥♥♥ING DO THE FILIA AIR COMBO WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥

(Ok seriously serious review)

Skullgirls is fun. Characters are all generally easy to learn, hard to master. Control are really well optimized for any kind of controller such as keyboards, SNES controllers, Sega Genesis controllers, Power Glove, and even a NERF gun! Tutorials are verywell fleshed out, but it's easy to say some are pretty darn hard, (Looking at air combos) but once you try one of every lesson (even if you fail miserably) you'll learn something, and that's ok.

The most negativity comes with the multiplayer in Skullgirls. Casul players CAN have fun, but quick matches quikly lead to 100 hit combo's with resets, or someone who has no idea how to play, just like you (or if you're a pro, cannon fodder). Most bad reviews come from salty players who didn't get 999 hit combos the first time they played. Multiplayer can be fun with friends, and lobbies are sometimes fun if trolls don't join casual lobbies and eat you.

Story, art style, and technical stuff in this game is very very well done. Controls are tight and responsive, and the community probably won't skin you alive when you eat questions (but seriously people are really cool here, I swear!). Overall, if you're a filthy casual like me, join me in the glorious ocean of salt and Fukua. reviewText:
Skullgirls is a fast-paced, drop dead gorgeous fighting game with an interesting and growing roster, one of the best tutorials for a fighting game and a helpful community. It's a must buy if you're interested in getting more serious about fighting games and a blast for playing casually with friends.

Despite never having played a 2d fighter beyond a really casual level, (although I do have a small competitive Smash Bros. background) it was very easy getting into the deeper parts of fighting games. The in-game tutorial gives a very good starting point. It explains basic and more advanced fighting game concepts and beyond that, there are brilliant guides and helpful individuals at skullheart.com, the dedicated forums.

The cast, albeit small, is intriguing and diverse, ranging from an amnesiac schoolgirl and her hairy parasite to a little girl-turned-cyborg wielding weaponry inspired by old cartoons. and soon, a saxophone man, dropping the beat on his opponents. The currently 9 characters have more than enough charm to make up for their lack in numbers, but there are 4 more characters (the sax-man Big Band, the egyptian songstress Eliza, the wrestler Beowulf and his trusty chair, and the enigmatic robotic version of Ms. Fortune) to be released over the following year that each have a free-to-download period thanks to the Indiegogo campain. And even after that, there is a sheer limitless character pool of astounding variety in the mind of the universe's creator.

The gameplay is fast and offers a vast amount of tools to be creative with your combos. No character plays like the other while the roster in it's entirety is incredibly well balanced. You can choose between fighting as one strong, two medium or three weak characters, allowing you to employ a variety of tactics and easing you into a team-based fighting style, should you be interested in such. The community and the developers have a great deal of interaction. This, along with the often updated beta version allow for fine-tuning and steady improvement of the already great underlying systems.

No matter how much you are interested in fighting game, Skullgirls is a great place to start, and a great place to stay!

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a 2D arcade action fighting game released on the PC in August 2013. The game was originally released on the consoles in 2012 and had great success.

Skullgirls differs from the fighting games that we have lately, in that you can actually fight in teams of two or three, as well as the single sided matches.  All of the rules are the same as usual, however in team matches, the team which has the most health when adding them all together wins in the event of the time running out.  Each of the characters have a wide array of move sets to learn, and combos. Some of the special attacks are just amazing to watch. The animations on all of the characters is absolutely flawless.

Since Skullgirls focuses a lot on the team matches, that means you are going to get plenty of double teams and dirty tricks being played by non active" characters

reviewText:
This is a review, that you should take to heart and shall help you to either decide to buy the game or not.
I love this game, if you couldn't tell. I play this game on a daily basis for 2 up to 5 hours a day and I will not get sick of it. I enjoy every second of it. From the music and stages, characters and their stories, up to the developers and voiceactors themselves; I just say, that I fell in love with this game. Of course, there are some flaws in this game, that I want to say in this review, so please, if you are not sure if this game is for you, then I hope, that I'll be able to help you.

The Game:
The game itself is basically what you get, when you throw Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat and your favorite anime waifu in a pot and mix it all together. It's a 2D Fighting Game with it's own certain mechanics and finally; Smooth 60 FPS. It is usually played with a Fighting/Arcade Stick, (Depends of how you call it) but on steam, you can play it with the Keyboard, XBox or Playstation controller... The choices are yours and yours only. If you prefer the Keyboard over the controller, go ahead.

The Characters
The Game has a selection of 14 characters, everyone of them with their own unique playstyle. As the title says, there are mostly only female characters. I repeat; mostly. With the exception of two characters, who are male, (Three, if you count Robo-Fortune as genderless) the rest of them are all female, but that does not matter. They all also have their own individual stories, which I like to tell you now.

The Story/Stories
The Story goes like this;
A mystic artifact known as the Skullheart has been created since multiple decades. It's power was to grant any girl's wish, if they were pure in the heart, but most of them weren't. If they were not, they turned into a creature, called the Skullgirl"

reviewText: A very unique art style that animates beautifully is the first thing noticeable about Skullgirls. While I'm far from a 'hardcore' fighting game fan, I enjoy to play these types of games rather casually, and enjoy facing off against friends. The 8-girl cast is a bit small at the moment, but over the next couple month, another 5 will be added to the list, including, for some reason, two dudes. The netcode in Skullgirls uses GGPO, and has been lagless against everyone I've played, and, unlike the console version, the PC version has a lobby system for facing people. This is certainly one of my favorite fighting games recently.

reviewText:
With fun combat and mechanics Skullgirls is a beautiful anime 2d fighting game. The art and the graphics are really nice and I loved the soundtrack (just do a YouTube search for “The Fish Man's Dance” and “The Legend of the Skull Heart” -my two favorite-  they are amazing!).
Game has a comprehensive tutorial, gameplay in general is really good.
The characters have a lot of style and personality, I love the cast, it’s very original. The only problem is that there are not enough characters since the roster is rather small.
As for game modes it has different ones, like single player story, arcade mode and vs. I’m sure you will have fun in every one of them. By the way, the controls are intuitive and responsive.
A must have if you are fan of anime and/or fighting games.

Con un combate y mecánicas divertidos, Skullgirls es un hermoso juego anime de peleas 2d. El arte y las gráficas son lindos y me encantó el soundtrack (solo haz una búsqueda en YouTube de “The Fish Man's Dance” y de  “The Legend of the Skull Heart” -Mis dos favoritas- son increíbles).

En cuanto a los modos de juego existen diferentes, como historia de un solo jugador, modo arcade y Vs. Estoy segura que te divertirás en cada uno de ellos. Por cierto, los controles son intuitivos y responsivos.
Un título obligado si eres fan del anime y/o de los juegos de pelea.

reviewText:
When I was a kid, I never dreamt about nightmares from bad movies like my other kid frineds. Instead in the middle of the night, my dad would wake me up and play maortal kombat 1 with me. It got to the point where it was the only thing I thought about before I went to bed.

Now I'm substantially older and despite thinking about other things a little more, fighting games wtill hold a special place in my heart. Well...GOOD fighting games rather. Mortal Kombat 9 has popped up with the old flair it once had, but I still feel like something's missing, Blazblue is SUPER fun, but not available for PC, so of course I was just in the dust because I've never particularly liked Street Fighter.

BACKGROUND:

So then Skullgirls pops onto PC, a port I've literally waited/anticipated years for. The port is WONDERFUL. The effort everyone puts into it is phenominal. Honestly. Coming from a crowdfunding IndieGoGo campaign raising almost a million dollars and NOT being Street Fighter, it's kind of a big deal.

Hand-drawn visuals are the only thing to grace this game and it never gets old seeing each frame of animation play out...unless you're losing probably lol. While playing BlazBlue I used to occasionally play in Mike Z's lobby when he got on, but I didn't really know who he was at the time. Apparently he was like a fighting god who was a real force in gaming & I held my own against his Tager, winning and losing equally. But little did I know HE would be the guy to give input on Skullgirls and help make it, basically making it his new way to live.

SYSTEM:

Skullgirls takes out a lot of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and just includes what's necessary" for hardcore 2D fighters. Although there are 1 or 2 features/mechanics I wish were in the game (and might be on their way in the future)
date: I've been pretty happy with what we have so far. everything is very straightforward and no 1-frame link ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t unless you want to make a custom combo yourself with unusual timing. And THAT'S another t hing. YOU can make combos the way you want. Implemented is something called IPS (Infinite Prevention System) that keeps people from performing infinites. Now this doesnt mean you won't get your ♥♥♥ whipped or long combos are out the game....quite the opposite
recommended: but it DOES mean everything is FAIR. If someone resets a combo
hoursPlayed: you'll know because of visual cues. If you keep getting hit before your attack comes out
voteText: the game will let you know with a red flash over your character
helpfulPercent: telling you you were just a biiiiit too slow and got counterhit. The system is simple
votesHelpful:
yet has depth for hardcore gamers as well.

GAMEPLAY:

To bring something new to fighting games
votesTotal: skullgirls combines the 6-button gameplay of something like street fighter
votesFunny: but mixes it with the combo-heavy nature of games like a BlazBlue. And also a really cool team-system is used. If you like playing solo with one character
commentsCount: you can use a REALLY strong character who has incredible damage
column16: or trade a little bit of that for a team of 2
column17: with regeneration when tagged out
column18: invaluable tag assists
column19: and Delayed Hyper combos. Things like make fighting games. It plays like BUTTER and the sense of impact is PERFECT. When you hit someone with a strong attack
column20: you will definitely feel it. And I really like that. Wonderful sound design
column21:
everything.

CONCLUSION:

And speaking of hardcore gamers
column22: the general pool of people who play this is one of quality. You will definitely be facing some good competition. And I'm very happy about that. So if you want to play this game
column23: I definitely recommened it. The people are GREAT and will help you if you need it
column24: and with nothing but more good features coming to it
column25: it'd be best to hop on now while it's still early!\n\nGame on :D"

reviewText: Oh boy.. What to say about this masterpiece.. Well, let's begin..\n\nSkullgirls is a modern take on classic arcade fighters with a hand-drawn high-definition twist. It’s a one-of-a-kind, action-packed competition complete with awesome combos and an intriguing backstory. Unlike other assorted fighting games, the game has a more feminine take on storyline and characters which is quite a relief considering most fighting games these days tend to become a full out sausage fest with all male characters who have the exact same personality and character development. The game is indeedly challenging and is very recommended to all fighting game coniseurs. All in all, this game is an exhilirating breath of fresh air and I would definetely recommend it (Unless some of you males are too scared to lose your masculinity to a fighting game or whatever :3)

reviewText: Finally another fighting game for the pc that is very well done, let's go by parts. Graphics, the game looks beautiful, all characters well done with details on every corner, the sprites are great, and the sprite of a fallen character can even be different depending on what kind of attack the character received before going down, the backgrounds are also well done, with lots of details everywhere, and the artwork is completely hand-drawn, and it's really not bad. Sound, the voice acting is very well selected for each character, there was one which I personally found kinda off before, Painwheel's, but now I see why it was chosen, the music very well done, each one sounding unique. Gameplay, the game runs 60 frames per second, completely smooth, all characters have different playstyles and feel pretty unique (Fukua is a clone character, she was made as an Aprill fools joke, as a parody of Decapre from Ultra Super Street Fighter IV, she was avaible only at the endless beta, but now she's a hidden character by she side of Big Band in the final game.). The game has almost no delay when the player presses a button, and it even has an anti infinite combo system. The game has local and online multiplayer, and the online multiplayer is very good, with a great connection, the player can create lobbies, with the maximum of 6 players, but the game itself might not be the easiest game for a begginer at fighting games, but the game has a very good tutorial mode, with even tutorials for learning how to use the characters, and the final boss is.... Very cheap to say the least, but certainly a challenge, and this game also has a gigantic number of references on it. At the moment all the DLC characters are not out yet, which when they are, they stay free for a limited number of time, so the player can decide if it's worth to buy the DLC or not, so when a new character is out, I'll test them, and if necessary, mention any change of anything at all, I will edit this review. I give this game a 9.5/10.0 a must-buy for fighting game fans.

reviewText:
A very well made fighting game, featuring small, but quite variable amount of characters who really feel unique and have their own preferences as to how they play. In addition to that, it has great tutorial which explains you the basics and hints as to how combo your moves/defend/pushblock etc.

You also have choice of either playing solo character or creating a team up to 3 fighters (which may have less health but can chain their strikes and cover each other).

Nice artstyle and music.

Best if you have people at hand who you know will not abandon it in case they find it hard. While the game itself is pretty fun, actually finding a match is very problematic if you're not playing Quick Match, sometimes you have wait very long for anybody to join your Beginner lobby. QM itself is pretty bad if you're new to the game, because of skill difference between newcomers and veterans.

reviewText:
Before Skullgirls, I totally sucked at fighting games! When I play Skullgirls, I still kinda suck! However, I think this game is pretty fantastic.

I was originally drawn in by the cartoony style artwork, but then after going through the tutorials and slowly getting the hang of how to play, this game has become one of my favorites.

When you're starting out, go through the tutorial, pick a character, and learn a few basic combos for him/her. After that, though it may seem daunting, go play some online matches! Yes, playing with other people is scary, especially when you think everyone else is better than you. You'll probably lose a bunch of times, but that's when you start to improve and learn more about the game's mechanics and whatnot. Soon you'll start to get a lot less worse then you were when you started! You can then invest hundreds of hours into this game (all of those two-minute matches really add up)! Wow, isn't that cool?

Also the online community's great; everybody's really friendly! Don't be afraid to ask the person who handed your booty to you for tips, he or she will most likely be willing to help you out and improve your game. The Skullheart forums are very sexy too.  Please check it out.

reviewText:
Most fun and polished game i have played in the last 5 years.

Gameplay : Solid fighting game, EXTREMELY FUN.

Visual art(s) - Cartoonish style that contribute a lot to this game, Awesome animations as well.

Sound Effects : Great sounds assets and of course goes without saying
Music : amazing music by Michiru Yamane (Castlevania: Symphony of the Night Composer - I would actually buy the game just for that).

Tutorials : Great Training mode, Covers a lot of the basics and more.
Performance : The game seems to be quite polished, Runs smoothly @ 60 fps.
I did not encounter any bugs or performance issues at all (Rare for both indie games and triple A games, SPECIALLY INDIE GAMES!).

reviewText:
And now for something spectacular!
Probably the best fighting game to debut in the last decade or so, Skullgirls is fast and super fun that is almost a must play for anyone with a even a remote interest in fighting games, made by a passionate team of individuals who really put their effort into making the best game possible.

Skullgirls has team-based fighting, similar to the Marvel VS Capcom series of fighting games, where you tag in up to three different fighters. Players can pick between fighting with one, two or three characters, giving the players a lot of different options to play with. The combat is fast and free flowing, which keeps the game very intense and fun. The free-flowing gameplay makes it really fun to experiment with different comobs. The gameplay is very technical for fighting game veterans to master, but can be picked up and played by anyone, so its good for both newcomers to fighting games and veterans. Furthermore, the tutorial is one of the best tutorials I have seen in any game of any genre. It literally goes over every aspect of the game in great detail so if you don't understand fighting games you can understand the more complicated mechanics with ease. There are also tutorials for every individual character giving guidelines on how to play and teaches you their special moves, which is great for helping choose which characters to main.

The artwork is amazing and beautiful to look at, as well as incredibly detailed, everything from the fluid character animations to the backgrounds is truly stunning, even breathtaking at moments. The soundtrack also fits the world and the fighting very well with some very cool theme stages.

Skulgirls probably has one of the strongest storymodes of any fighting game. The storyline is very engaging, the dialgoue is executed perfectly by the voice actors and the characters are all unique and interesting. What really makes the game stand out is the sense of humour, this game is one of the funniest games I've played, with very funny dialogue, even the announcers are memorable and produce some great lines. On the downside, the storymode is a little on the short side. Some people would complain about a lack of characters, since there were only eight on launch, however, they have since added six new player characters to the game and all the characters are unique and interesting and I would much rather have a small cast of characters that are all unique instead of a large cast with some duplicates and less interesting or fun characters.

Multiplayer in this game works very well, especially compared to some other PC fighting games' netplay *cough* Accent Core *cough*, you can almost always have a great match with little to no input delay. One of its faults is that there isn't a challenge mode or many extra modes like in other fighting games.

Highly recommended for both fighting game veterans and new players alike! Can't wait for what Lab Zero comes up with next!

reviewText:
As someone who hasn't played 2D fighters for long, I can say that this is a great introduction to the genre. The game comes with an amazing tutorial going over all the basics that help one get started. There is a total of 30 lessons, and each character has a lesson specifically for them, which teaches all their special moves. If you're planning on buying this game, I recommend having a controller or an arcade stick.

Characters
There are currently ten characters, or eleven if counting fukua (Fukua is a variant of Filia with a different set of moves). More DLC characters are currently in the works aswell. The current roster is smaller compared to other fighting games. However, The qaulity of each character is worth a small roster. Each character has a unique playstyle. For example Cerebella is a grappler, who specializes in throwing her opponents. There is also a lot of synergy between characters, since one can create a team of multiple characters. Before a match one can choose to roll with a team of one super-powered character, two high-powered characters, or three normal-powered characters.

Another thing cool about the characters are the various palettes. Each character has about 20 unique color palettes. Some are original, but others are based off other fictional characters. For example there are four palettes based of the anime Madoka Magica and a palette of fionna from Adventure Time. The palettes just add a lot more fun to the game, though simple things.

Community
The story mode is pretty short, and like most 2d fighters the focus is the multiplayer. Playing with people can be challenging for begginers, since people who aren't the same skill level will show drastically. When I first joined a quickmatch my opponent was a lot more expirenced than I, and he didn't pull any punches. Luckily there are lobbies for beggingers, and there are tons of people willing to play with somone on their skill level. I'm not sure how many tournaments are hosted for skullgirls, but I did find a group, which holds a newbie night tournament. There was also a side tournament that happened at evo 2014, and I imagine it will be there in the upcoming years as well. I believe there was a $5,000 cash pot, so there definatly is a reward for mastering this game.

Features
This game comes with a variety of ways to play. Singleplayer comes with a story mode, where one can choose any of the characters on the roster and learn their backstory inbetween about three fights and the finally a fight with the skullgirl herself. It also features an arcade mode, which features competent AI bots to fight. When wanting to train, The traing room has a lot of options that can be turned on and off, so you can setup the perfect envimorent to train any skill. Finally the multiplayer has quick matches, lobby play, an a local tournament function. The lobbies in skullgirls can be created to hold a max ammount of 8 people, and you can either spectate or fight someone in the lobby.

Conclusion
Skullgirls is definatly worth the purchase. It's a really stylized 2d fighter that looks and feels great. It's easy to get into for begginers, but hard to master. You'll be having fun playing this for hours upon hours, if you aim to harness you're full potentintal at this game.

reviewText:
Did not think in a million years I would be into a game such as this. I picked this game up on extreme sale (under $3) and for the first time ever, picked up a DLC within a few days. Do not let the hand drawn animations fool you, this is one exciting game.

Skullgirls is about a mystical skull that appears every 7 years. It's power can be held by a soul but the soul can easily be manipulated and cursed if not careful. Here's the issue though, as soon as the skull re-appears, the whole city goes nuts. Skullgirls by it's game play definition is a fighting game. Upon playing the game, I noticed a few similarities between Street Fighter IV and this game. The move schemes are slightly similar but I feel they are lot more effective and simpler. Meaning, more moves that seem extremely challenging to do in SF IV, can be done with a bit less intensity and damage to your controller. The combos are insanely ridiculous though. Unlike SF IV, you're not stuck with one fighter.

You can have up to three in your party. This means when doing special moves, you may have another character come jumping in randomly. Although this is a really cool feature and an awesome offense, you'll have to be double careful as if they miss they can get damaged as well. 1 character vs 3 should be strong enough as they seemed to have gone to great lengths to balance it all out. The moves are pretty smooth and combos up to 30 or more hits can be executed. I feel this game is a lot more free" in the sense that you're not scripted to press this button after you've pressed this button. Okay
date: maybe there is a little button mashing involved but it seems like control chaos. I feel a lot more immersed in this game than I do in SF IV as I feel I can string more successful combos together. There is your basic light
recommended: medium and hard punch and kick but there are also buttons to call in for support (if available). There are a few modes available in game such as career
hoursPlayed: versus and extras (where you can view the gallery or even fight the main boss but at 300%). The campaign was actually well done. It follows a comic strip sort of dialogue where characters expressions and backgrounds will change accordingly.\n\nObviously
voteText: there will be breaks in between where you have to fight another character. I really like how the campaign was done as you only have to fight each person once. Some may argue (and have) that it's made the game slightly short. With all the characters available though
helpfulPercent:
you should have at least 4-5 hours geared towards this particular mode. Each character has a different story that is being told. Some characters will need you to beat the campaign before you can move on and use them. The DLC characters even have stories but I found one or two sort of are gimmicky.

The visuals in this game are absolutely fantastic. It's hard to believe that it was hand drawn. I personally don't find any lack in this sort of animation style but some have brought to my attention it seems to "jumpy" for them. This shouldn't be an issue for you as the game play will certainly pull you in. The animations done for certain moves are absolutely insane. Big Band for example or Double have some crazy animations regarding their attacks or when they get hit. The sounds are actually really good and you'll hear characters chime in before and after matches with a quick insult.

Overall
votesHelpful: this is a great game. I would highly highly recommend buying it on sale but if your a fighting fan
votesTotal:
you may want to get it full price.

reviewText:
Without question one of the most forward-thinking fighters in the genre right now. While keeping true to its 2D-fighting game roots, LabZero recognizes some of the flaws and annoyances from other fighting games and seeks to correct them.

Faulty netcode? Nope, we've got GGPO.
Unexplained mechanics? Nope, pretty much everything you could want is given to you in the tutorials. More than that, it's done in a way that will challenge newcomers without overwhelming them.
Unblockable setups? Handled.
Unbalanced metagame? Not here. Game design is lead by MikeZ, who has been a part of the fighting game scene for a long while now. In addition to that, balance testing is regularly handled in conjunction with the playerbase itself in the form of the Endless Beta.

The community is currently not too big, so the players you'll find on quick match are generally somewhat skilled and experienced. Because of this, the game might be difficult to get into for a newcomer. But it truly is worthwhile to keep practicing and improve your skills.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Skullgirls overall is a beautifully done game. Amazing soundtrack, fantastic animation, and fast-paced gameplay make this one of the best fighting games on the market.

Now, this game is not for everyone. Compared to games like Street Fighter, it's much faster and seemingly more random until you get the hang of it. People often say that this is one of the best games to pick up as your first fighting game, but I don't necessarily agree. Yes, it has one of the best tutorials in fighting game history. Yes, combo'ing from normal to normal (normal=punch/kick) is easy. However, the mix up and reset-heavy nature of the game can make it seem like you're just being hit until you die.

I 100% recommend this game, but I do think the barrier to competency is extremely high...but that's not a bad thing. And if you're just looking for a fighting game for you and a friend to play for fun, then Skullgirls is perfect. Just don't expect to put even 50 hours into it and expect to win very much. If want to sink some time in this game to git gud
date:
then it's very rewarding.

It's also updated fairly often with very reasonable balance changes (I'll miss you, Filia's j.lk j.hk overhead crossup), new characters (Beowulf hype), and game features (the new replay system will make it very easy to see just how much of a scrub we all really are.  This is MikeZ's baby and he pays attention to it.

Summary: Great game. High barrier to competency, but can also be played casually with friends who aren't too familiar with the genre. 9.5/10

reviewText:
I can't recommend this game except to people who have spent comprehensive time with fighting games. I wanted to like it, but ultimately regret the purchase.

The art style and animation is a strong point, and the characters are enjoyable if you don't mind heavy fanservice. But, the actual gameplay is pretty terrible towards newer players. The tutorials establish fighting game rules pretty well, but they really don't help when playing against other actual people. The matchmaking prioritizes internet connection over skill/ranking, leading to a ton of matches where you will literally put down your controller while someone lands a 50-hit combo on you.

This leads to a game that is extremely off-putting to casual players, as it doesnt allow you to gradually improve by playing others of your own skill level. Learning the basics through the fantastic tutorials will not help when getting regularly matched against veterans that only need to land one hit to win the match.

Perhaps it's better if you stick with a small group of friends. But, with the emphasis on overly-long combos and inability to consistently play strangers of your own skill level, I would recommend SSFIV or KOF over this fighter for casual players. Only buy if it's on a really good sale or you are otherwise accustomed to combo-based fighting systems. It's really a game for veterans, which unfortunately I was not.

reviewText: This game shows you don't need to be some giant AAA studio to make an excellent fighting game. This game is a pretty nice mix of gameplay from the Guilty Gear series and Marvel vs. Capcom 2. Netcode is pretty solid, best training and tutorial modes in years, and nice soundtrack. I wish this game had a bigger cast even with the future DLC characters but given all the careful design and constant updates to the character and engine, I understand the limited size of the cast. The game from first glance may seem like some niche anime fighter but give it a chance and you will see it's a great game that also has a pretty cheap pricetag.

reviewText: Skullgirls is, in my opinion, the best 2d fighting game of this generation. It is, for all intents and purposes, the true sequel to Marvel Vs Capcom 2. While it does have ideas and a style of it's own, it stays true to the fundamental logic" and ideas on what makes a competitive fighting game fun and smart that fueled MVC2.\n\nThe game allows you to select a team of 1 to 3 characters to fight 1 on 1 and switch out with the next character when defeated or low on health. Health and damage are balanced based on how many characters you have on your team

reviewText: Skullgirls is currently the most fully-featured fighting game available on PC. It has an excellent tutorial and the gameplay is extremely tight. The cast is well-balanced and each character (as well as the game in its entirety) is interesting. The combos are a bit long, but relatively easy to perform. A skilled player will beat a novice one hundred times out of one hundred. The neutral game is very intense regardless of the matchup. This game is going to have people playing it for a looong time.

reviewText: Fantastic visuals, tight controls, incredible soundtrack. If you're into scantily-clad cartoon girls whaling on each other, this is the game for you! Skullgirls is a good beginner game if you're interested in other fighting games. Unfortunately, it suffers from unbalanced characters and a relatively small playerbase. In the event you do find someone online to fight, they're probably going to be frustratingly good, or have no clue what they're doing, effectively estranging intermediate-level players if they don't have their own friends to play with. It is a cool game but it did not survive in the long run.

reviewText:
Short Review:

You can beat up a giant cyborg saxophone man as a depraved bisexual ninja surgeon.

Buy this game if you like fast-paced fighting games with MVC-like gameplay.

Do not buy this game if you do not like gratuitous fanservice and boobs. (Why the ♥♥♥♥ would you not like that anyway?)

Long Review:

Skullgirls is a fighting game about having a stupid plot, it's absolutely ridiculous, the gameplay on the other hand is absolutely fantastic, being a Marvel-like fighter without the ridiculously broken characters that the community would curse at you for using, having a anti-infinite combo system that checks if people are using the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over in a single combo and tells them to ♥♥♥♥ off if they are, and allowing to choose between one, two or three characters on your team, allowing you to play the way you like and not punishing you for not being able to get your ♥♥♥♥ right with the other characters.

The graphic style is anime-ish, and looks nice, the game also uses actual drawings as sprites and not models or...sprites, which looks even nicer when you notice that the game actually pays attention to lighting, darkening the characters when they get closer to darker places.

The soundtrack ♥♥♥♥ing rocks, tell your kids to stay away from this game, there is too much SAXual content, your kids will end up JAZZing unintentionally all over the place due to this.

Overall I give this game a Stylish/Fancy.

(Refer to the game's combo names.)

reviewText:
A solid fighting game, you have your basic story which all ties in with each character, of course there's the multiplayer too.

The multiplayer is where I think the game really shines, with a variety of characters (some are DLC but are on sale as of now so grab them while you can!), a range of moves and combos, mix-ups, resets, it is the fighting game inspired by other fighting games.

Wanna duke it out with one Uber character with a heck of health and damage? Maybe use two really strong and durable ones, or use three normally spread characters and kick, some, Skullkeister.

Very balanced, easy to pick up, and user-friendly!

The tutorials do a great job of defining and demonstrating what exactly this game is about. You get two kinds of players on this game, some are very, VERY adept and talented, and some that are just learning and here for a good time (like myself).

There's some real satisfaction in pulling out some combos, and especially duking it out with friends! If you don't have any, get some, if they don't have Skullgirls, make them get this game, you will not regret it.

Hey, you don't have to take my word for it, I just really reccommend this game, normally it costs £11.99 (about $18.99) and now (at the time of original post it was) £2.99 (again, about $4.99), it's a deal to be a fool to miss, if you love fighting games!

Additional note: Use a controller, a keyboard is not recommended, I REPEAT, a keyboard is not reccomended, thanks for reading! Also, pick up this game :D

reviewText: This 2D fighter is somewhat like MvC and Guilty Gear in that the combos can be a bit long, but you do get to escape them if they go on long enough. The netcode in online multiplayer is really good and it's what I mostly play, but sometimes you won't meet anyone in the online queue for a while. There's a decent amount of people that play the game online, altough it will probably be a bit hard to find an equal match when you start out. Fighting stronger opponents will make you a better player though, and the training mode has a lot of options to help you out.\n\nIf you like fighting games with wacky characters this is well worth the buy.

reviewText: Probably one of the best games out there nowdays! I myself love this game I have it since the beggining when it wasn't Skullgirls Encore and was only for PlayStation and XBox. The game is fast paced, easy to combo, has a fluent gameplay and also has an anti-loops system. New players will find funny to mess arround with Fortune's Head (#Meow) or just hit multiple keys and make some awesome tricks they never seen before. Mastering this game is a challenge but pretty rewarding and fun! This game also includes an endless beta for players to test what's coming up to the game and it will always be free. reviewText:
Probably one of the best fighting games I ever played along with Dragon Ball Z Budokai 3 and BlazBlue.
It's a brilliant fast paced fighting game with a playstyle like Marvel VS Capcom where you can make your own different incredible teams to fight your friends, enemies, or frienenemies.
Sure the character roaster isn't really large compare to most other fighting games nowadays but this gives the characters more clearer and interesting personalities that have their own playstyles (which can be very balanced for the most part)
The only few problems I is that the game dosen't have as much content as alot of other fighting games and the game can be quite difficult at times but there are many ways you can get use to the game like training or play it on friendly difficulty for new players.
Overall I think this is a really great game. If you are a fan of fighting games or someone who would like to try out fighting games in gerneral, I would highly recommend it and give it a try! :D

reviewText:
Skullgirls' combat system is very unforgiving especially to new players. There is very little room for error in an SG match.

First off, the combat is very fast paced and relies on 50+ hit combos that leave you with roughly 50% HP left. That doesn't sound so bad, but it doesn't end there.

Metagame relies a lot on resets. This means that getting hit by combos leaves you in a defensive position just right beside your opponent. And from there you have a split second to guess his next move or else you get hit by another combo again.

Did I mention almost anything starts a combo? Overhead moves, instant airdash overheads, special moves, and even normal grabs can lead to combos that shave off roughly half your life. So after losing half your life from the first combo, you have only 1 or 2 chances to properly avoid his next move or else you get hit again by another combo effectively killing you or leaving you with roughly 10% HP in just a couple seconds since the start of the match. Skullgirls seriously needs a better combo break mechanic and/or more HP on it's characters as there is very little breathing room if you're on the losing end of the match.

Another frustrating thing about SG's online play is that you spend more time waiting for an opponent rather than actually playing against him. Keyword there is PLAYING. Because spending the match sitting there while watching your opponent use your character as a combo training dummy does NOT count as playing (again, little room for error).

Skullgirls' visuals and sounds are amazing however. The HD hand drawn high frame sprites are impressive. And the overall character and background design along with the music fits well with the Gatsby era theme.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a fighting game that takes some notes from Marvel Vs Capcom 2. It's got some really great art and animation, some character designs that I personally really dig, a really cool jazzy soundtrack, really fun gameplay, some surprisingly alright writing, and probably the best, most clear and concise tutorial in any fighting game I've ever played.

Another thing worth mentioning is the art gallery. Skullgirls has some genuinely stellar stuff, and the art gallery lets you look at stuff ranging from animation key frames to concept art and arena backgrounds. It also lets you look at several pieces of guest art, quite a few pieces of which are pretty awesome alone. If you enjoy looking at concept art and all that jazz, you'll find plenty of it.

I've never been a huge fighting games dude, but Skullgirls' tutorial taught me just enough to start really enjoying them, and it's a really awesome game in it's own right. If you're looking to get into fighting games, this is a good one to start with.

reviewText: One of the best 2D fighters I have played to date, all of the art is hand-drawn and gives a very unique and distinct feeling. The game plays sort of like Marvel vs Capcom 2 but is still very different. One thing that makes this game stand out from other fighting games is it's tutorial, most tutorials just have you placed against a dummy and displays some moves on screen however Skullgirls gives you a real introduction to the game. It teaches you basic fighting game mechanics which is beneficial for teaching beginners and can still be refreshing for experts. Despite all of this the game can be very challenging due to it's incredibly high skill cap. All in all this game is amazing and is worth every penny it's especially a steal when on sale. If you've ever wanted to begin to play fighting games or are looking for a new one Skullgirls is a must buy.

reviewText: This fighting game is an absolute marvel to witness. Extremely well animated characters full of personality, punchy, satisfying sound effects and very well polished gameplay that takes from the likes of Marvel vs. Capcom and Guilty Gear. If you're unfamiliar with combo-oriented fighting games like this, Skullgirls is an excellent place to start with an extremely helpful tutorial that will start you off on the right foot. This game can be brutal for newcomers, but with enough determination and experimentation, you will impress yourself with the things you can pull off.\n\nIf you want a gorgeous, well supported game with a high skill ceiling, look no further.

reviewText: Best fighting game ever. Solid tutorial and relatively simple mechanics and specials inputs make it really acessible but complex enough to be enjoyable. The art is amazing and each frame is hand-drawn, which makes it stand out among others, few characters but each feels very different and are hard to master. Amazing music and the best netcode I've seen in a fighting game(PC Fighting games are often notorious for having bad online modes, which just kills the game). Story mode is kinda weak aside from the DLC characters, but that's about the only problem I have with it. Just really great overall, if you want to get into fighting games, this is your best bet.\n\nPlus it has waifus.

reviewText:
I wasn't expecting much from Skullgirls when I bought it, but it more then exceeded my expectations after playing the game for more then just an hour. This is a six button fighter that can be played with normal powered teams, a strong tag team, or an overpowered single character. The option to be able to choose how many chatacters you want to bring into a match allows you to play the game in a numerous of ways, and brings different learning curves.

The in-game tutorial is the best I have seen in a fighting game, to date. This is a good place to start with fighters, just for the simple fact that it tries to teach newcomers the nuances of the genre, and not just combos. Although, there are plenty of advanced combos that require precise execution and memory, that put games like MvC and Blaz Blue to shame, if you are interested in high-level play.

Controls are fluid and responsive, any time my fighter did something I didn't intend for her to do, I knew I was at fault and that it wasn't due to bad mechanics. Combos are easily to learn and execute but like all fighters, require some time to learn. I have tried playing with a Keyboard, Gamepad, and Arcade stick, and can say you will probably need a pad or stick to play this game. Don't get me wrong it is very possible to play with a keyboard, (and from personal experience, actually kinda fun) but it will be hard to play characters who rely on Z motions.

The 2-D sprites are detailed and animated fluidly. The developers did a good job incorporating each characters personality into their fighting styles, if you can appreciate such things. Each character even has their own animation and properties for their tag ins and outs. (something I wish Marvel had)

Even though most people probably don't go into fighters looking for a story, the game does feature a story mode, that has suprisingly good lore, and interesting characters, with a final boss that may well rival Shao Kahn. So even if you are looking for a single player fighter, there is something to be found here.

reviewText:
This game is a suprise delight. Someone bought it for me, and i wasn't expecting to really get much out of it, but now it's quickly become one of my favourites. I've purchased the game 3 times now (once on xbox, and twice for other people), as well as some merch.

The characters may not seem like much upon first impression, and there isn't a huge roster to choose from (There are still a good few choices), but you'll grow to like them a lot. Each character is unique, and you can tell that the developers really put their heart into giving each character a distinct playstyle, as well as an interesting personality. There's something for everyone. The game itself just feels very smooth and comfortable, and the art style, and animations are GREAT. I've never seen a game that looks as nice as this one.

This is also a great game for beginners to the genre. I am one myself (And by god was i bad when i first started.), only just getting into them recently, and the tutorials in this game were very clear and in depth, and will teach you enough to get started. Of course if you want to be decent at the game you will need to put in more time, and really learn the game. Veterans will love it too. There is plenty of depth, and it doesnt cut corners.

The developers really put a lot of love into this game too, with frequent updates, often featuring new content, and even more characters are on the way. Also, each new character DLC is free for a few months, to thank those that chose to support the game early, so if you buy it now it will pay off.

This is the kind of game that if you put some time into it, you will really grow to love it. If you think you will enjoy this game, you probably will and even if you don't expect to get too much out of it, it might suprise you. In short, if you think you may enjoy it, then buy it. It's well worth the price.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a 2D fighting game.
It has a small cast of well-balanced characters. It has an anti-lag system put in place that allows me to play almost indiscriminately without latency issues. It has a combo-blocker feature preventing your character from being locked up in a chain of infinite hits without a chance to retaliate. It has, and I don't say this lightly, a superb tutorial mode to teach you the ins and outs of the system generally, and specialised ones tailored to help you learn individual characters.

As I said, Skullgirls is a 2D fighting game. If you enjoy such games, you should most likely enjoy this. If you find yourself randomly button-mashing in Tekken and wanting to improve, you should almost certainly appreciate this. If you don't care for such games, you should give this a miss.

Basic pancakes recipe
A delicious and easy pancake recipe that is fast to get on the table and better tasting than any convenience pre- packaged mix.

Serving Size:
8

Category:
Basic recipes, Breakfast, Budget, Cakes & Baking, Dessert, Easy recipes, Kids cooking, Kids food, Lunch box, Pancake recipes, Snacks

Prep Time:
5 mins

Cook Time:
10 mins

Ingredients:
1 cup (150g) self-raising flour
1 tbsp sugar
1 egg, lightly beaten
3/4 cup (180ml) milk
50g butter, melted
Method:
In a bowl mix flour and sugar.

Beat in the egg and then milk at little at a time until batter is smooth and lump-free.

In a hot pan or flat grill, brush butter over cooking surface and pour 1/4 cup measures for each pancake.

When large bubbles form on the surface, flip over and cook until lightly golden on the other side.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a a fighting game by an indie developer which actually able to deliver solid experience in gameplay mechanism, take a direct rivalry into bigger and old player in its industry, mainly japanese.

Visual style is cartoon with a jazzy, old school theater theme. It's a little bit dark too, with a tremendous amount of fanservice, so this is not quite fit for your child play. The animation sprite is jaw dropping: very detail, a lot of works put into it, it's simply GREAT. Meanwhile the cut-scene and background seems like very rough, in some point feels not finished and looks like made in a very rushy work.

You want to take air domination in the game? use Filia. Wanna troll your enemy with projectile spam from down and above? use Peacock . Wanna play music while fighting? use Big Band (I'm dead serious). Every single character is very unique, in a way that some char feels specifically designed to be some 'specialist' in a particular playing style. The roster is small, but it speaks quality, that's quite amazing, not to mention that developer doing a very good job to make sure all the char is well balanced.

Especially for a newcomer, it will be very worth it to finish the tutorial stage. It's explaining all the things you need to know in the world of 2D fighting game, as simple as possible. I found out that learn from Skullgirls tutorial is way more fun than learning from other more complicated game like Blazblue.

So you buy the game and jump into it, and feels sucks as combo doesn't connect, you got humiliated in the online play, or feels that Marie is too god damn broken? Fighting genre isn't like other major genre in video games, it puts you directly into the stage with your true skill, so you must be sucks in your early hours. Most people do. Please accept it, put a work into your practice room, learn from the pros in the internet or youtube, and when you feel ready, try to jump into net play again, and prepare to being sucks again. Rinse and repeat.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a very accessible but deep fighting game that combines the pick up and play of the Marvel vs Capcom series, with the big loose combos of Blazblue/Guilty Gear.

If you're new to the fighting genre, this is probably the best place to start, the game has easy controls to learn, as well as one of the most informative tutorials I've ever seen for a fighting game.

If you're a veteran, you can put together some wild combos, and with the inputs being on the easy end of fighting games, you can spend less time trying to punch in 63214632146LK LP like some games, and more time reacting to enemy movement with your standard quarter circles, DPs and charge attacks.

Overall, go get this game! It's well balanced, well designed, with likeable characters and movesets!

reviewText: Marvel vs Capcom 1 players will feel right at home with this title. Dishing out a string of combos is pretty simple and satisfying to do. Players can get real creative with combos. I would recommend players use a PS4/PS3 or a wired Fight Stick for this game. I also advise new players to  just hop on the game, play a a couple single player matches to get a feel for the game's mechanics then immediately shift over to tutorial mode. Take a look at the Community Hub for character guides and controller mapping guides.\n\nSkullgirls is a highly additive and competitive fighter and will continue to grow. It's definitely worth a buy.

reviewText: Skullgirls is an excellent game. It takes elements from my favorite fighting games like a ratio system, team matches, assists, etc, and manages to improve them further with things like custom assists, an infinite prevention system, automatch round scaling for 1v1 fights, etc. In addition, the dev team has been incredibly involved with the community in tuning and balancing the game as much as they can. I feel like it's the first fighting game to have what is essentially a living design" that is present in so many MMO's and expandable/collectible tabletop games.\n\nThe character art and animation is among the best in hand-drawn games
date: hearkening back to Darkstalkers and really only rivaled by vanillaware titles. Despite the intial stigma as an "anime cutsey-fighter
recommended: Skullgirls is one of the best fighting experiences I've had in recent memory; if you're a fan of fighting games or looking to get into them, I hands-down recommend it.
