reviewText:
My review is going to focus on the mechanics of the game but let me say this game has everything:

- The story, presentation, graphics and audio create a wonderful universe.
- The interactive tutorials teach you about the characters, game systems and fighting games as a whole (mix ups, hit confirms, etc.)
- Best tools in practice mode of any fighting game I know of (I've played A LOT), including hitbox and hitstun display, slow motion, 'as reversal' dummy playback, savestates and more.
- GGPO netcode.

On to the actual fighting. Skullgirls can be played with mixed solo characters and teams of 2 or 3. Health, damage and defense are scaled so it's balanced. I prefer teams of 2 and occasionally 3, but a solo character can overwhelm a team if they get the momentum. Teams have assists and tagging similar to Marvel, though you can use any normal/special/throw attack as an assistant and all characters have unique tag in attacks.

I really like the amount you can customise your team. It definitely helps offset what some might see as a limited roster of characters.

Speaking of characters current cast of 12 (eventually to be 14) are all very unique and represent a wide variety of styles. My favourites are Big Band, the slow armour character that can actually play music (also he can parry), Cerebella, the grappler that also glides and can reflect projectiles, Valentine, because she's a ninja and can move wherever she wants and Eliza, the stand" character. There's also a Scorpion/Angel hybrid stance character
recommended: a dismembered cat girl with rekkas (and is also a doll character) and Fukua
hoursPlayed: the joke character that has a dragon kick so win all round.\n\nAll characters have special moves and supers
voteText: for the most part very much like Street Fighter moves. Supers use 2 buttons rather than double motions. If playing with a team you can tag mid super into the next characters super. There is however no ability to perform multiple simultaneous super moves.\n\nCombos are largely formed out of chains
helpfulPercent: going in traditional "magic series"
votesHelpful: though there are links and plenty of unique chains. The combo system is very free form
votesTotal: the limiting factors are the infinite prevention system (IPS) and drama/undizzy bar. These limits are a good thing
votesFunny: they keep you from repeating the same thing over and over
commentsCount: keeping combos interesting and stopping any single combo from going on for too long. There are still high damage combos but you can't just loop something until timeout or death.\n\nIf a combo starts to loop the player getting hit can burst out for free. This means you have to either end your combo or try to reset the other player into another combo
column16: or even bait the burst and attack after.\n\nThere are many unique character specific systems that make the game interesting and give the characters more depth. Big Band can parry attacks
column17: Squigly can cancel normal attacks and move the screen around
column18: Valentine can inflict 3 status effects and resurrect dead teammates
column19: Painwheel can fly and absorb then reflect damage
column20:
and so many others.

Character diversity is definitely one of the games strong points.

So in summary
column21: I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves 2D fighting games or would like to start playing them and to anyone who likes fighting games and appreciates the story and art. If I had to put a number on it I'd say 5/5

reviewText: It's a great game with superb graphics, But I'm sure you've already heard all that before. The characters are all hilarious. (Yes even double) the gameplay is simplistic but can be deeper if you want but once you know the basics with this game unlike other fighting games you can stand a chance when fighting people better than you, HOWEVER THERE ARE SOME PROBLEMS TOO. Once you miss a block, get ready for a 36 second 48 combo. seriously that's just really annoying... Another thing is the zoning in this game is HIGHLY exploitable for people who don't know how to counter it, I picked peacock and double/big band and I would have the assist knock them to the edge of the screen and spam perjectiles then slightly mix things up. It would grant me a win more times then I should have... And it's not even that I was more skilled then them or anything like that.. At first I thought this was fun but after being kicked countless times and then being kicked from a livestream. I thought maybe the kickers had a point... Am I going to stop being a spammer online if I'm fighting a n00b? NO. because it's an easy win. A skilled player would not lose to such shinanagins...

reviewText: I've played about 300 hours of this on my PS3. It's more in line with Marvel vs Capcom, but slowed down a little bit in a  good way. New players of the fighting game genre should find solace in this title as it has a solid tutorial that nudges you and gives you raw facts about how fighting games work, even going so far as to mention and explain a multitude of fighting game jargon most wouldn't understand. The game is slowed down in a way that positively makes it feel different from other titles which also lends itself to being easier to read, something most games fail to deliver on. Combos are intentional, opportunity windows are fruitful for engaging in a back and forth bout every fight, character balance is spot on, and every character feels unique. They hit many of the generic character archetpes found in Capcom fighters so if that's your main jam, you can bet your but you'll gind a character to like here. There was a lot of care put into this hand drawn game and you can tell it's made by people who truly love the fighting game community and fighting games. If you like Capcom fighters or MVC, pick it up, it's worth the money!

reviewText:
Skullgirls is honestly very addictive if you're the kind of person who enjoys playing games with a heavy emphasis on fighting. Coupled with is very pleasant to look at art, and some very interesting character designs, it's an all around solid 2D fighter.

However, I think the biggest problem is that the keyboard controls are a little bit hard to master. That isn't to say it is impossible to play with just a keyboard (since that's how I've been having to do it lol), but it would more than likely be a lot more immersive if one had a gamepad. Aside from that minor annoyance, I am very much enjoying this game.

The fanservice (or in some cases disservice) may not be for everyone, but if you don't particularly mind the gainaxing and body horror, and if 2D fighting games are something you enjoy, then I would recommend this game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is quite a great fighting game to pick up regardless if you are a veteran fighting game player or just looking for some fun in casual games. I had some expectations for this game since I've first heard about it years ago and so far it has surpassed them.
First thing first ~ The Art:

Beleive me when I say this is a beautiful game. All sprites were hand drawn with a combination of western and eastern styles and have a high number of animation frames, making them move quite smoothly. The use of 2D characters in a 3D engine works well in making the characters feel like they belong in the enviroment. Honestly, it's better if you just take a look at the game to see what I mean.

And if you're into them: Boobs.

Fight! ~ Gameplay:

The game has a six button lay out for three punches and three kicks, allowing for a large variation of combos and tricks. Each character has unique mechanics that seperates them from the rest of the cast. The game does a good job of being accessible for both veteran fighting game players and those looking for a fun time with friends. The game also includes an in-depth tutorial for basic fighting mechanics and for specific charaters you want to play. Do note: Like any other fighting game, you'll have to invest a lot of time into this game if you want to play competitive, espacially if you rarely touch a fighting game before. Seeking help is not a bad idea, which brings me to...

Saved by the Fans ~ The Community:

I've had very little interactions with the Skullgirls community. However, it has been very welcoming and it has a lively following, which has kept the game alive for this long. Go look at the Indiegogo campaing for more information.

All there in the Manual ~ The Story:

What you expect from a fighting game story: people beat up people, roll credits. It starts of slow, and not much is even reveal during the actual game, forcing you to look up the lore on the internet. But it doesn't fail at giving each character their own personanilty. It isn't until the DLC Characters where the story actually gets exciting.

In A Moment's Time ~ The Music:

The soundtrack does its job of setting the atmosphere in both fights and story segments. However, the tracks don't really stand out too much from each other and are forgettable if you're not crazy about music. This is, of course, more of a personal opinion.Overall: is worth picking up along with the DLC characters. If you are even a little interested in this game, it won't dissapoint.

THAT'S A WRAP!

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that Skullgirls isn't for everyone. If you don't like arcade fighting games, well, you probably won't like Skullgirls.

That being said, if you do like the arcade fighting genre in the slightest this is a must-buy game.  Mechanically the game is among the best as far as fighters go but it's the memorable characters, beautiful artstyle and the imaginitive world on top of the extremely polished gameplay that take this game from being 'great' to being 'absolutely amazing.'

Skullgirls is great for beginners looking to get into the genre as well, offering an extensive tutorial mode that covers the basics all the way up to mechanically-demanding mixups. (Combos that are unpredictable) Sure, tutorials are common in fighting games, however, the sheer depth of Skullgirls' tutorial is what makes it deserving of praise.

Mechanically each of the characters are as diverse as their personalities. Through the tutorial you'll learn each character's role and weaknesses and as new characters are added they're given lessons in the tutorial as well, giving all the more reason to endlessly praise Skullgirls' tutorial.

The roster, although seemingly tiny, is being rounded out by additionally characters being added in future patches. At the time of writing this, three of those characters have been released with the remaining two being actively developed which round out the diverse roster of characters beautifully.

That being said, the game is constantly being updated and patched with no sign of the developer stopping any time soon.

The game is fanservice-y, yes. Is it tasteful? Honestly, yes, it's appropriate in the context of the game and the characters
within it. If you can't handle female characters in sexualized outfits/poses then I don't know how you've played any other fighting game to be honest. The problem isn't that the characters are designed this way, it's that you have overly selective eyes and an extremely closed mind.

So here’s where we’re at when all is said and done: we have a fighting game set in a gloriously original world, racked out with unique characters whose hand drawn animations are stunningly detailed. The soundtrack of the game is – at least for jazz fans – beautiful enough to warrant an OST purchase all on its own. The graphical presentation is phenomenal, the story mode is entertaining, the characters are unique and engaging as a whole. For fans of this genre do yourself a favor and purchase this game. At the $14.99 price point it's a steal as it's worth double that at the very least.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is honestly very addictive if you're the kind of person who enjoys playing games with a heavy emphasis on fighting. Coupled with is very pleasant to look at art, and some very interesting character designs, it's an all around solid 2D fighter.

However, I think the biggest problem is that the keyboard controls are a little bit hard to master. That isn't to say it is impossible to play with just a keyboard (since that's how I've been having to do it lol), but it would more than likely be a lot more immersive if one had a gamepad. Aside from that minor annoyance, I am very much enjoying this game.

The fanservice (or in some cases disservice) may not be for everyone, but if you don't particularly mind the gainaxing and body horror, and if 2D fighting games are something you enjoy, then I would recommend this game.

Put the time in and this will become one of the most rewarding fighting games you've ever played. I guarantee that.

reviewText:
When I first heard about this game I was very skeptical but my god am I glad I gave Skullgirls a shot! This is one of my favorite fighting games of all times! If you like actual fighting games then pick up this title! It's so awesome, with the team options there is so much diversity! Each character is so different to and when I saw that I mean VERY different, not the classic street fighter style of you have a different punch but you're basically Ryu. Every character is balanced to, sure there are always exploits like all fighting games but against a decent enough player cheesing won't work. My favorite thing about the game, aside from the handdrawn art and the company itself, is that if you don't want a 'team' you don't have to. You get to choose between 1-3 characters, the less characters the more HP they have. The story mode is nice as well, especially with the DLC characters in it. It's very fluent and writing is pretty good, unlike this review.. writing isn't my strongest suit. With the announcement of 2nd Encore I even recommend this game even more, because us steam folk will be getting that as well: with more story, more gameplay modes, and I think more characters!

So yes buy this, the only fighter I ever liked more than Skullgirls has been the Guilty Gear series and that alone should be enough of a reason to buy it :P

reviewText:
After around twenty + hours of playing Skullgirls, my experience so far has been pleasurable. It’s an incredibly fun,addictive game that draws you in without you even noticing, feeling like a triple a title instead of an indie game. It’s fantastically creative art style is refreshing and the soundtrack is wonderful (especially Skull Heart Arrhythmia - get's you pumped!), providing a really nice, comfortable fighter experience. The only other fighting games I have played are MK v DC, Street Fighter and Smash Brothers (does that class as a fighter?) but skullgirls completely blows these games away, sustaining a feel of fresh gameplay every time I play it, where I’m constantly learning new things even after the extremely helpful and noob-friendly tutorial that helped me out a lot!
So overall:

Pros:
- Fresh art style
- Fantastically well designed characters, makes you want to experience the story and find out more details.
- Multiplayer (versus) is fast and fluid.
- Tutorial is one of the most informative I’ve seen in a fighter.
- The gameplay is smooth allowing you to mix up your combos quickly, tons of fun!
- Playing with friends is a breeze.

Cons:
- The only real criticism I could give Skullgirls is its matchmaking system. If it was based on skill level instead of pairing you quickly in a match/joining a randomly titled ‘Beginners welcome’ match and getting locked in a 90000 hit combo, I believe the game would have a bigger online community. However, having said that I learn more from fighting tougher opponents than those on the same level as me.

reviewText:
In terms of fighting games, Skullgirls is by far my favorite.

The team are balanced, and the combo system allows for individuality:
Not every team you see will play the same way, and each match therefore different from the next.

Learning to play the game is easy!
The tutorials are expansive and user friendly, even for people that are new to fighting games!
The community is very supportive and provides feedback on gameplay to help newer players advance.

The character list may be relatively small when compared to other games.
However upon further exploration you will find the differences between each character more than make up for it.
No one character is anything like another in terms of moveset, strategy, etc.

So whatever playstyle you prefer, there's bound to be character for you!

The team system allows for endless possibilities in terms of competition and strategy.
Teams are well-balanced, and so a team of 3 is just as good as a team of 2, etc.
Playing solo is not punished, as you are compensated for your lack of teamates in terms of damage and health.

Much awaits you in the world of Skullgirls, and it's only getting better!

But don't take my word for it, try it out for yourself! You won't regret it!

reviewText: Skullgirls is an excellent game. It takes elements from my favorite fighting games like a ratio system, team matches, assists, etc, and manages to improve them further with things like custom assists, an infinite prevention system, automatch round scaling for 1v1 fights, etc. In addition, the dev team has been incredibly involved with the community in tuning and balancing the game as much as they can. I feel like it's the first fighting game to have what is essentially a living design" that is present in so many MMO's and expandable/collectible tabletop games.\n\nThe character art and animation is among the best in hand-drawn games
date: hearkening back to Darkstalkers and really only rivaled by vanillaware titles. Despite the intial stigma as an "anime cutsey-fighter
recommended: Skullgirls is one of the best fighting experiences I've had in recent memory; if you're a fan of fighting games or looking to get into them, I hands-down recommend it.

reviewText:
Great game, great graphics, great mechanics, great boobies.The game itself is amazing.


Then you go online;
>Almost NO players
>When you do find one, the ping is higher than the Eiffel Tower
>Then you find one guy that pings below 100
>He infinites you and you don't even know how to act in these situations since you can't really practice online
>Ragequit ALT+F4, you'll probably play again in 3 months

*This part of the review is not to be taken seriously

Let's get right into it.

PROs :
-Smooth and nice 2D graphics.
-The ecchi aspect of the game is well-tought.
-Mechanics are great, a bit trapping but fun to master.
-Lots of combos, special moves.
-A lot of easter eggs, from other games to animes.
-Good characterization and overall story.
-Nice features like the art gallery and more.

Sadly, there's the whole problem about the game's online mode.The multiplayer aspect of the game isn't really optimal, you hardly find any persons to play with and compete at the same level.Most of the times I find myself looking for matches for about ~10 mins of quitting lobbies because of my opponents' pings(I can stand 100 or a little more ping, but I'm talking about 200+ ping);
All the lobbies I find are always from the US, and there's only a few of them anyways.
My tips for the developers are to publish the game more, the online really needs more players, and along with that, the ranking system should be improved.Some research filters would be nice, just so you don't get frustrated over quitting dozens of lobbies because of the opponent's ping.

Well, all things considered, the game is awesome and I highly recommend it to any fighting game fan, the game is compatible with any controller, you can easily play with a keyboard, the Story Mode is fun and interesting, Arcade mode is kinda challenging.
The devs are kind, for example every DLC character is free for some time before having a price!

Vote : 10/10Totally deserved vote, the game is magnificent as of now, and has a lot of potential to be even more in the future!
Worth buying at ANY price, it gets discounted to ~4€ a lot too.

reviewText:
I loved the look of this game even prior to when i so kindly recieved it as a gift for my birthday this past June. I love the animation, the fighting, the soundtrack (even if you don't like anything else, you can't say no to the soundtrack) and even the developers. I LOVE EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME. I think the only reason it took me this long to write a review was because i didn't know how to explain all of it's awesomness.

You can tell these developers love their fanbase and they're treating us oh so nicely... other companies, here's a great example of awesome developers. They're letting their fans vote on which DLC characters get in, as well as said DLC characters being FREE for download up to 3 months after their release. And sure the DLC list may be pretty small at the time of this review, but as long as the developers are being supported, there's more coming our way!

But enough of that...

The Good:
- The animation
- The characters
- The soundtrack
- The backgrounds
- The voice acting
- The DLC (on that note, before Big Band's release, we even got Fukua. Although meant to be an april fool's joke, the developers kept her in due to her being a fan favorite. So you may or may not count Fukua as an extra DLC character)
- The story (especially the DLC characters Squiggly, Big Band and Eliza, at the time of reviewing)
- Unique feel to the characters
- The multitude of popculture refernces (have fun finding them all)
- The narrator (COME ON DRUNK NARRATOR VOICE PACK! GET RELEASED ALREADY!)
- The game play
- Training Mode
- ABSOFRUKLY EVERYTHING!

I honestly can't think of anything bad to say about this game. And trying to think of bad stuff to say about it brings up little annoyances but nothing that breaks the game entirely or would bother anyone to the point of a rage quit (with maybe one exception).

The little annoyances or 'the bad' if you will are very minor things that you learn to deal with eventually or can just avoid at your leissure. Maybe it'll bother you, maybe it won't, but that depends on your play style and tolerance to fighting games.

- Peacock is a keep-away  character and will spam her bombs and other cartoony antics at you until you've been his so many times by little 8-ball bombs that you get a little frustrated or own her via block buster moves. First time playing, she annoyed me at first but you get used to fighting her own time and will develop ways around her multitude of bombs and planes flying at you constantly. (and for a 90's kid like me, the fact she makes so many refferences to well-loved cartoons is also a plus. i giggle everytime she says 'Hellooooooooo Nurse!')
- Fukua, a character added through a patch as an April Fool's joke (to poke fun at SF's Decapre). Her story mode seems somewhat random compared to the rest but you fight all of the characters in your roster with Filia as the final boss. AND OMG FILIA AS A BOSS IN FUKUA'S STORY MODE WAS SO FRIGGIN DIFFICULT I RAGE QUIT MULTIPLE TIMES. I eventually figured out how to beat her or at least keep her down long enough to attack so i beat Fukua's story mode... But fighting Filia as a final boss in that storymode... you'd think the game was hacked or on Nightmare mode even when you have it on Easy difficulty. I promptly gave her the nickname 'cracklia' because she moved so fast and rapid that i didnt have time to make Fukua react... You will get your ♥♥♥ pummeled mutliple times over before you beat Fukua's story mode (the ending though... is fanfic worthy...)
- Some moves that require you to move the analog stick or directional buttons diagonally and in a certain pattern really confused me (could be because i never grew up playing XBOX though, so it may just be me still adjusting to the controller). These moves are a challenge to pull off in training mode, often resulting in my skipping training
- Big Band is overpowered compared to a lot of the cast, which might make you rage quit your first few times fighting him but you can find ways around it similar to fighting Peacock. I'd still prefer fighting Peacock to Big Band though
- Without the DLC characters the original roster was 8 characters. Fukua is now included through a patch so you may say there are 9 characters in the base game now?

That's all i can really say about the so called 'bad'...

But before i end this review, i need to say something serious (and i don't mean to sound feminist)

I feel it's ok to have your waifus and fanservice girls in anime, manga and games. I don't say boo to a female character with a large chest, butt or anything else for that matter. In fact sometimes these characters are enjoyable because they can bring comedy or light-heartedness into a story. To me even the 'fanservicey' characters in Skullgirls feel really balanced and don't let their ♥♥♥ or assests define them entirely. I feel these characters are a perfect harmony between actually having a personality with depth and also not being afraid to show some leg ;3

But one thing that annoys me about Skullgirls isn't anything that's the developers fault.

It's the people who assume this game is soley for fanservice and gawking at oppai all day.

>:( and i'm NOT bashing either gender, BOTH genders are equally guilty for this rant

Often these monsters never even play the actual game and just look at it and say 'oh, all those characters are ♥♥♥♥♥ and ♥♥♥♥♥s because their chests are a certain size and they have lots of panty shots' That honestly breaks me down as a female gamer... I'm not a feminist or trying to sound that way, but those people need to fruk off. These are the same people who think even awesome and powerful Bayonetta is solely a sex symbol and that if a girl is in a game, she's a sex symbol or for fanservice or any other number of dumb, stupid, uneducated reasons.

Skullgirls makes me happy to be a gamer (who just so happens to be a lady).

It's giving the gaming industry some more strong female characters without having 'FEMINISM' written on the cover art. It's bringing together MALE AND FEMALE gamers who can play together in peace and not have an argument over sexism and equal rights for women. All the girls in this game kick-♥♥♥ and are awesome to play as. They're strong, powerful and confident girls who i love to accompany on their adventures to get the Skull Heart. And as far as feminist arguments go, leave these characters alone. Don't you want strong female characters? Here, you got a game with 8/9 of them to start with. Enjoy your DLC.

Rant aside, this game gets 10 Skull Hearts out of 5 :) have fun~

reviewText:
First off I'm really late to the party even though I've been aware of Skullgirls (SG) for a minute but why is that?

I love fighting games and been playing them for years but what put me off SG was the Marvel"-type of gameplay when you got a ton of characters on the screen at the same time just throwing ♥♥♥♥ out for the sake of it. I like my fighter a bit more clean. That and all the negative things I've heard about the game (mind you this was when they game was brand new).

But recently I decided to give this game a try
date: mainly because I really like MikeZ and wanted to support him
recommended: and I'm really glad I did. This game is great!\n\nYou can tell that MikeZ has put a lot of thought into this game and if you play other figthers you wish that some features that SG has was the standard.  Like what's key for a good fighter nowadays? Good N E T C O D E
hoursPlayed:
period.

Too many developers overlook this or simply doesn't care because they know that their game will sell anyway (NRS etc) and that's just sad. I haven't played Killer Instinc online (heard great things about that netcode) but the GGPO rollback netcode for this game is by far the best netcode I've come across. Thank you based MikeZ!

Everything else about the game is just fantastic! Great visuals has it's own style which gives this game it's own identity and it also has excellent music to accompany that. But the thing I like the most about this game is the character designs and their respective playstyle. They're so cool and fun to play and for the most part really easy to pick up and play. I don't care if some ideas are borrowed elsewhere because I think it's cool as long as you build and further exploring the possibilities of that borrowed idea. And clearly this is the case here.

The only thing I don't like is that there are too many clone characters in the game (sure they play very differently but they're still clones) and I'm also aware that some of them are in there as a joke but that doesn't change the fact they're clones

reviewText: Picked this up while it was 3 bucks. Totally worth it selling my purple bill's hat in TF2 to afford it. reviewText:
If you want to step into fighting game, get Skullgirls.

This game has one of the best tutorial which is good to players who want to move on from a usual button masher to a fighting game player.

The one that really hooked up with this game is the characters. Each character have their own personalities, motives, and implication in the series lore. Their personalities come out in the gameplay, with their moveset or quotes. The story mode, while not very long like Blazblue, are interesting and added more personalities to the characters. Each characters has their own story yet none was stated canon, which open many more narrative possibilities.

The setting of the game is unique to the fighting because of the jazzy feeling they give. The soundtracks are great, especially the theme song.

The developer also done good jobs on fleshing the characters while listening to the feedback from the player. Their blogs are interesting and informative. With more of DLC characters come up, I can't wait to see what they are up to.

Even though I'm still getting beaten up in online play, I still enjoy the game, especially playing with friends.
Get the game!
Get the DLC! They're good

reviewText:
Very big learning curve. However the extensive tutorial helps with that. Once you know how to play it becomes one of the most fun fighting games you will ever play.

Although, one problem I have with this game is the way the tutorial teaches you. It does not tell you what buttons do what moves, (ex. A is Light Kick and X is Light Punch) instead it what the buttons do and that tells you how to do combos. (ex. <- Hold -> LK) But that's just a small little gripe I have with it.

The Animations are great, the Art Style is awesome and the banter between the fighters is awesome. It's a fantastic fighting game and I highly recommend it.

In conclusion, this is one of the fighting games I've ever played

reviewText:
tl;dr: A really good game for $10-15, despite being indie it holds up very well and surpasses the big fighting games in certain aspects.

+ Good artstyle
+ Easier on the move execution than other popular fighters
+ Solid game balance, no really OP or UP characters
+ Decent newbie playerbase

- The artstyle isn't for everyone
- Some characters are a lot more popular than others
- No replay system yet (keyword: yet)

reviewText:
This game, is a beautiful gem that seems to be underrated! It is even though, a typical fighting styled game, is but of brilliant as the beginning to starting your fighting gaming addiction! With it's addictivly Western x Japanese Jazz Soundtrack, and cute girls that kick each others asses, it's more than worth your money, including the beta to test any changes in advance towards the game.

Yet even though it's fun and a great time-waster, I felt more effort could be put into it. The storylines of each character and how fast-paced each campaign goes is just too fast and rushed, with some of the line-art still a bit dirty and unclean, it gives off a sense of imcompleteness, but sometimes, it's these flaws that create something unqiue, and enjoyable. Having quite improved AI than other fighting games, it also has beautiful revamped animations and backgrounds that are just tantalizing! Being made with love and care of some of the staff now creating Cryamore, I can't wait to see the developement and improvement of this game.

It's worth your dollar, and it's a fun time-waster all for a small price! 8/10, must try for beginner fighting gamers~

reviewText: I've played this game and have enjoyed it quite a bit. It has a nice, simple, and cartoonish art theme that translates into a fighting game quite well. It is incredibly fun to play with friends, and you can match up with people online. Lab-Zero has done an excellent job of creating this game and is still updating it frequently; more characters, patches, bug fixes, and other tune-ups are fairly often. In my book, I think Skullgirls was worth the money, and if you do decide to buy it, you will not be left disappointed!

reviewText: Skullgirls, let's talk about this game. Skullgirls is probably hands down my favorite fighting game. While more technical fighters certainly exist, this game nails exactly what it's going for. If you're looking for a fighting game that can ease you into the genre, I'd suggest this hands down, the tutorial teaches you everything basic you need to know from walking to more technical play, to a character by character breakdown! With a diverse cast of different afflicted women (and now a few men) with strange powers, there's certainly no lack of variety. The game has an amalgation of mechanics from several fighting games such as Marvel Vs. Capcom 2, Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Heritage for the Future, Guilty Gear and so on, not to mention a range of subtle to not so subtle references to comics, anime and media in general. It's easy to spread the basics you learn here to other fighters and pick those up as well!

reviewText:
Tell me if there is anything wrong with this review and I'll be sure to change it

This review is from the heart so its bound to be long as hell

Skullgirls is a 2D fighting game in which every single penny is worth it's purchase price.

This game was my first fighting game of this stature and probably THE best game for anyone wanting to get into the genre
(We'll cover this later)

The games first impression is a solid one as you're thrusted to the menu with some smooth ♥♥♥ jazz music

The game has 3 main modes, the single player, the multi player, and the training mode

The single player includes, story mode, arcade mode, and a cpu quick match. The story mode provides a unique story depending on the character you choose, the lentgh of the story (for each character) can range from 15 minutes to an hour depending on the difficulty you are playing on (The Fukua story mode is a ♥♥♥♥♥!) which welcomes a good amount of play time. These characters are also charming in their own right as their personalities each differ and make for some pretty good story telling.

Speaking of characters there are a total of 14 characters however 5 of them are DLC (1.99 Each) these characters each have their own unique playstyle which will be the preference to the player wheter they like grappling characters, combo characters, or characters that require stratagetic placement of their moves. This was a very welcoming feeling as I hardly felt that any to characters were the same(Besides Filia and Fukua).

Each character also has 25 unique color palettes to choose from which really showed how much these devs cared about the culture nowadays and their product. Every time there was a color pallete based on another game and I was able to recognize that I immeadiatly said to myself Yeah these devs get me"

The multi player is solid as all hell and I rarely ever saw the framrate dip because either me or the other player has a bad connection. Although the quick matches for some odd reason don't work all the time for me
date: the lobby matches worked perfectly. However if you dont practice enough with your prefered characters and deside to jump into a lets say a quick match you are going to get your ♥♥♥ beaten ALOT. As your opponent will rack up combos and combos and combos against you which is my only real issue with this game. Even though their is a built in mechanic where infinite combos aren't allowed I still found at times people were able to do such things (or I just suck)\n\nThe biggest praise i have for this game is its extensive tutorials
recommended: these tutorials cover everything to standard movements
hoursPlayed: blocking
voteText: advanced techniques
helpfulPercent: mix ups
votesHelpful: and even diving into specific characters with their movesets and how they play best. This tutorial is the very reason why this is the first game i recommend to anyone who wants to get into the genre.\n\nStages are varied and are mesmerizing to look at
votesTotal: music is also funky to listen too even outside of the game
votesFunny:
and frame rate is always consistent.

This game is one of the best indie and best fighting game I have ever played. This game overall rightfully deserves a 9/10 from me.

Thanks for reading"

reviewText:
A game designed by MikeZ, so right off the bat you'll know you're going into a combo heavy game. Interesting character designs and the game takes from a lot of different (but same combo heavy type) fighters.

The game was originally started based off of MvC2 so that's where most of the tag team aspect comes in. The matches can be anything from (1-3)v(1-3) (CvS2 ratios). If you have more than 2 players you get to choose your assist (mvc2 style) but you can also use a custom assist which can be as simple as a lp or as advanced as a different move which is not originally selectable. DHC's are in this game so if you whiff a super you can DHC to another character which has a safer on-miss option.

Probably the only unique thing about SG as a fighter that I've seen is the IPS (infinite prot system). If a combo reaches stage 5 and the same attack is used to open up the next loop that had been used in the previous stages the opponent will glow pink and can hit any attack to burst (GGXX)" and end the combo. I've still seen doubles that have taken 90% of my HP in a no meter combo so I'm still unsure how this works.

Fairly well constructed with GGPO lobby support
date: but the game still has a ways to go."
hoursPlayed: true
helpfulPercent: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Story
Every character has their own story, but all of them are linked to the skull girl, an evil being that grants a wish to unwary girls, just to posess them after they die... only after they get killed by another girl they shall be free, thus repeating the cycle.

Gameplay
This fighting game is pretty cool and entertaining, though there isn't much depth to it. Too few characters, but you can see the studio put a lot of love on every one of them. Besides, they add more from time to time, so don't think it'll be always like this.

The combos are good and there's plenty of gratuitous panty shots. Lots of fun for local multiplayer. Every character has their own set of attacks, so while some are pretty easy to control (Ms. Fortune), others are a bit harder (Big Band). Amazingly good casual fun, but the more you play it, the more you wish there were more characters. It'd add a lot of depth to the game.

Graphics/Soundtrack
Everything's pretty much in 2D so there isn't much to say. It isn't demanding in any way so if you have a low-end computer you should have no trouble running this.

The soundtrack is good for a fighting game. It does its job, though it's not the kind of soundtrack I'd want to keep in my music library.

Controls
This is very important. If you're even remotely thinking about buying this game, get a controller. For some people it might be obvious, but I was fool enough to think I could play it with my keyboard.

Observations
None to make at the moment

Breakdown
6/10 good fighting game, but few characters. Hoping that'll be fixed at some point.

reviewText:
Let see now, I remember buyin skull girls for the X360 back when it first came, I'm still playing and getting my ♥♥♥ whooped but I dont really care cuz this is a GREAT FIGHTING GAME.

* TO NEW PLAYERS *
This is worth your $10.00 (price at current time of post) and to tell the truth you don't really need to puchase the DLC character right away. It's more fun, YES, but before you invest your $2.00 (per character... WORTH IT!) on new characters you have to make sure you get your basics down. Also don't worry about losing all the time, it's discouraging sure, but if you played dark souls then losing only makes you better.

reviewText:
Well to start off to sum up this game in one word: Amazing

A legend tells of a heart which almost destroyed the world, The Skullheart. The skullheart is said to give a wish to any female
but if your wish is unpure then you will become the skullgirl somebody with immense power which in time will destroy them and the world if they cant be stopped.

The stories of each character is so unique and compelling it keeps you at the edge of your seat, chair or wherever your sitting.
The artwork is incredible, its so beautiful and bright; oh but dont thing its all rainbows, they have some dark colours too which has a contrast that you cant quite put your finger on but regardless you love it.

The training mode is great for beginners, novices or expects alike, finding it easy because of the simple options to make things easier, helping you train to create combos or make combos and even vs a cpu to test your skill.
You'll find yourself a treat when you do certain things in the game and you unlock some wonderful artworks and character concept designs and now onto the story mode after you beat 8 of the wonderful characters you meet Marie the boss of bosses who laughs at Saiko from KOF XII and then see if the girls can subdue they wishes and destory the skullheart or will they ask for a wish which will go unheard its up to you to find out....

reviewText:
All in all, Skullgirls is a very good Fighting Game with a robust tutorial and is also easy to jump in to. The great aesthetics will certainly attract a lot of casual player but it is the great fighting mechanics that will keep people around. The PC Version does have its problems but with how Lab Zero handles things it will only take a few more time to fix those minor issues. If you like fighting games or wanted to try playing a fighting game that is easy to learn, looks great and still have enough depth to satisfy a veteran fighting game player, Skullgirls is a must buy. With the price of $15, it is really worth it.

Full review:
http://xkrieg.blogspot.com/2013/08/skullgirls-review.html

reviewText: Skullgirls is a 2D fighting game that pays homage to the classic arcade games that came before it, while updating what needs to changed in order to keep up with today's standards. If you grew up playing 2D fighters, then you will feel right at home here. If you didn't, then it's still a great game to get you introduced to the genre; with a cast of characters small enough to be balanced and simple enough comands that aren't exactly as complecated as other fighting games.\n\nEasily one of the best parts of Skullgirls is the presentation of the game. With many recent indie games like Shovel Knight favoring using 8-bit graphics in order to induce nostalgia on those who grew up in the NES era, I am more than glad that this game didn't do something similar. In my opinion, Skullgirls has the best graphics of any game in its genre. The sprites for the characters are all handrawn, and it really shows (in a good way). Not only that, but the world that the game takes place in is very unique and stylized. You get a sort of futuristic 1940s" vibe from the Canopy Kingdom
date: and I love every second of it. The music fits the setting and style of the game perfectly as well
recommended: with a laid back jazzy feel to it.  Although I will admit
hoursPlayed: I am very biased towards jazz music and you may not like it personally.\n\nThe actual gameplay is very much what you would expect. It is a 2D fighter
voteText: very much modeled after MvC2. In fact
helpfulPercent: the two feel eerily similar. And seeing that MvC2 is still considered one of the great tournament fighters 15 years after it's release
votesHelpful: that's not necessarily a bad thing. So if you're a pro at that game
votesTotal: you'll pick up Skullgirls pretty quickly.\n\nMost of the negatives to the game are very nitpicky and I won't dwell into most of them that much. Some elements of the story (especially the lore) aren't really explained that well; but it's a fighting game
votesFunny: so the story isn't really the focus. The game is much more balanced than something like MvC2
commentsCount:
but only for it's vastly smaller roster. There are a few characters who are a little unbalanced.

And speaking of characters...

There is one major complaint that I will dwell on into a bit of detail: is Skullgirls sexist? Most fighting games are...er...bouncy
column16: but Skullgirls in particular has gotten a fair bit of attention for it's main cast of characters being entirely female (the only two playable men in the game are DLC characters)
column17: and some of these females being very...well...yeah
column18: they got big boobs. I'm not avoiding it. People are getting all wound up because of the sexualization of most of the characters. As a straight young woman myself
column19: I feel like my opinion is welcome in this debate: I think it's fine. What makes a character sexualized or not is how they show off their assets
column20: not ther assets alone. And even though there is a character who is literally a sexy nurse
column21: the detail and effort that went into how they move and attack is really something to behold. So are the characters sexualized? Yes
column22: but it could have been much worse. Not every character is sexualized
column23: and all of the designs and ideas behind them are very well done (even the sexy nurse).\n\nAll and all
column24: Skullgirls is a fantastic game that delievers everything it promises and more. If the sexualization of the character turns you off a bit (or maybe uncomfortably turns you on ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°))
column25: I can't really say I can recommend it to you; but if you're looking for some classic 2D fighting with some style
column26: then this game is perfect for you.\n\n8.5/10"

reviewText:
It definitely reminds me of MvC2! First of all, it seems pretty balanced, from a technical point of view. It reminds me of MvC2, a lot, but more balanced. I think if you ever enjoyed that game, you'd be able to enjoy SG a lot!

I absolutely adore the quirky animation, art style and music. Hell, said music? it's by Michiru Yamane, who does work for Konami on Castlevania!

Frankly, the only things that bug me about SG are the understandably small roster, the fact I can't cross up someone in the corner by jumping over them, and that Marie is a bad final boss who reminds me of Dust of Osiris from MBAACC.

I would highly recommend this game if you like/liked Marvel vs Capcom 2 and fast 2d fighters in general(Guilty Gear, Blazblue, Darkstalkers, etc etc.)

reviewText: Got it for the excellent tutorial. Stayed for an excellent game. Skullgirls is an impressive piece of software - for starters, it really helps you get into the game, while not explaining the base fundamentals of fighting games itself, it does a good job of showing and explaining its own systems and mechanics. Inputs are mostly quarter-circle motions, so if you have ever thrown a fireball in Street Fighter you are good to go - the rest is down to timing the various attack buttons to unleash all kinds of devastating combos. Skullgirls is probably the closest thing we have to MAHVEL" on Steam
date: but it takes inspiration from so many other fighting games and adds its own spin on things thus feeling pretty unique. Pick up to three characters and duke it out in a tag-team super battle!\n\nThanks to the indepth tutorial and the limited amount of characters (10
recommended: if you include the two DLC characters) it is far less overwhelming than the competition - however
hoursPlayed: if you want to "git gud" prepare for some brutal encounters online and spending time in the various training and sparring modes to practice combos and different situations.\n\nSkullgirls is nicely flashy too
voteText: with gorgeous artwork
helpfulPercent: excellent animation for a small studio and some really outlandish designs that rival some of the craziest stuff other fighting games throw at you (this is coming from a Darkstalkers-fan). The jazzy soundtrack feels like a nod to Marvel vs. Capcom 2 and complements the action nicely. There are a lot of nods and references to other games like that - from color palettes (I have spotted various Street Fighter
votesHelpful: Soul Calibur and even Killer Instinct outfits) to various characters appearing in the background (that training-block from WakuWaku
votesTotal: OMFG!)
votesFunny: even Wolverines Berserker Barrage made it in - it is great fun discovering all the little things. But there is more than just fanservice
commentsCount: Skullgirls features a lot of niffty comfort-functions too
column16: like it tells you when you are in the life-lead or lets you switch a versus match to sparring mode on the fly to test stuff out.\n\nOnline is very solid thanks to GGPO
column17: however - I haven't found a way to fight people on my level and as mentioned before online WILL make you humble
column18: so many beastly killers around that will combo you to death with ease. Still

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a team-based fighting game set in its rather original world full of colourful characters, dark stories and general weirdness.

Using general premise of games like MvC, SG has rather conservative (in terms of numbers, at least) roster of rather diverse characters with quite a bit of options. Development team constantly works on the game, regularly patching bugs and other issues and - what's, perhaps, the most important part - constantly experimenting with existing characters in BETA build every SG player has access to. New characters are added every now and then and as of now, at least two are yet to be released in addition to a dozen of existing ones. If you have the game when those are released, you'll have them for free btw.

The game can be fast and complex enough for FG veterans to feel at home, while keeping basic inputs as simple as possible. Combined with very decent tutorials, it makes SG pretty welcoming to new players, including those not very familliar with competitive fighting games (even if it's probably not the simpliest FG to become average or better at, but it's understandable given it's premise). It can be pretty fun to play casually too, and it helps that visual style, while possibly repulsive at first glance to some people, is pretty creative and occasionally funny, can be pretty decent party game.

Basic idea (teams) of the game can be describled somewhat like this:
- You pick a team of 1-3 different characters, smaller team has more HP and damage per character;
- You control one of them while you can call others to assist you or to replace your point character";
- Assist move is chosen before the game starts
date: it can be any of normal or special moves available to the character
recommended:
plus every character has one move that is used specifically when she's called to make an entrance and stay.
- Fight until only one team has someone left standing.

It's simple
hoursPlayed: but can lead to rather deep gameplay - if you choose to go there
voteText: of course!\n\nWould definitely recommend for gameplay
helpfulPercent: artstyle and for the fact that this game has developers' support that every fighting game should have in my humble opinion."

reviewText:
A somewhat new, and certainly note-worthy addition to the 2D fighting arcade genre.
Not only can you tell how much work has been put into it (I've watched some of the Lab Zero live streams and can confirm), but there's a good system set up where you can not easily abuse an infinite combo chain.
Well... unless you have no idea what you're doing or your skill does not even come close to matching up to that of your opponents.
That is my only complaint about the game.
It's a very addicting and fun arcade fighter, but I've come to a point where the CPU level is too easy even on Nightmare difficulty. When I switch over to online, you have people playing that are even more pathetically easy to beat, or they're the complete opposite and you are going against some ridiculously skilled opponent or spammer where you will not even be able to move a single bit the entire round due to being constantly attacked.

Other than that, it's fun if you enjoy a challenge, and clean looking, and I've had no problems with frame rate or anything of the sort. Also boobs, if that really seems to be a key selling point for you.
And Lab Zero still puts out DLC, so there's some great things to still look forward to.

reviewText:
I walked into this game expecting another anime game with girls with large boobs and skimpy clothing -- and frankly, it kind of is. But this game goes far beyond that with its gameplay.

I was instantly sucked into the game because of the great graphics (that don't crash my computer not designed for gaming -- yay) and incredible artwork. I'm not into the big boobs and skimpy clothing scene, but this art style still tops the art for most games I see on the market these days. The characters have emotions and they look great as they battle with creative moves.

I read that this game had impressive and smooth movements and wonderful gameplay and I put it to the test and I'm not even done with the first story mode session and I already know that this game was worth everything I paid. I still have a lot to learn about this game but one session in, and you'll be hooked.

reviewText: I believe you should buy this game right now. It's great, but complicated. Online play will see you crushed by a 50x combo, but the singleplayer is just as good, and if you keep upping the difficulty, you may have an actual chance in multiplayer. This game is also better with a controller because of crazy 360 joystick combos. But with practice(A LOT OF PRACTICE), you may pull off a 360 combo with your arrow keys. The constant patches and the new upcoming DLC characters(Which will be free if you buy the game before they're released)are more reasons to buy this game. And even if you don't buy the game in time, I think you should still get at least 1 DLC. I bought Squigly for 5 bucks, and that'll probably be the price for future DLC characters. ( You know, after they're FREE) This was a long review, but in short, this is a cheap Indie game that's worth the 15 dollars. 10/10.

reviewText:
Probably my favorite fighter currently on steam (though it seems ASW has added some titles recently).  Overall a fantastic game that I would highly recommend.

The gameplay itself is great, with the only real issue being the limited roster (hopefully to be fixed with the addition of more dlc characters which are free for a short time).  Each character has a number of combos they can preform and no two players will likely play a character the same way.  Additionally, the ability to control 1,2, or 3 characters in a match adds more depth by adding the options for assists and comboing with meter attacks (meter being known as dramatic tension" in skullgirls or something like that).

The gameplay can be a bit complicated (not unusual  for a fighter) and new players can be quickly overwhelmed if they jump into an online match right away (most opponents will be better than the AI opponents on nightmare difficulty).  Thankfully
date: skullgirls has an indepth tutorial system that is probably the best I've seen in a fighting game.  It covers every major gameplay element and serves as a wonderful introduction to the basic principles of 2d fighters.  Seeing as many aspects such as blocking and mix-ups are done similarly in Skullgirls as they are in many other fighters
recommended: the tutorial system makes Skullgirls an excellent place to start for those wishing to break into the genre.\n\nThe soundtrack of the game is excellent and does a good job at setting the mood of the game.  It isn't the most memorable
hoursPlayed:
but it is certaintly better than average and a few tracks in particular stick out.

Visually the game excells.  The character models are drawn beautifully as well as the backgrounds and attacking frames.  The character design is excellent and left me with no misgivings as to the success of the game in the male demographic.

Overall
voteText: I'd put this at about an 8.8/10 making it my favorite fighter currently on Steam.  Would highly recommend."

reviewText: Alright so when I first looked at this game I wasn't exactly expecting what I got when my friend sent me a copy of it. I expected just another 2D fighting game, decent multiplayer, and lots of super-pointlessly sexualized women. That's not what I got at all! Sure three or four of the main eight were rather big-boobed and little-clothing'ed but honestly this game isn't even about that. This game's storyline is great, and if you look more into it online it only gets better. I actually cried over the ending of the DLC Character Squigly's campaign. I've never cried over a video game let alone one with a storyline it took me 30 minutes to beat. So if you're thinking about picking this up but are wondering if it's really worth it. It is. The multiplayer is fun and rather intense so it's good to play with friends. The story modes are totally replayable, and all the characters are unique and have diverse and incredibally interesting backstories. So I leave you with a good luck because the vanilla controls are really hard to get so I'd suggest re-mapping them to your perfered setup. Have fun ^_^

reviewText: Now before I get started I would like to say that I don't play that many fighting games on a competative level aside from Smash Bros. I've played games like MvC3, Ki, and Mk9, which are all good but eventually got stale to me. So why in the holy f**k do I love Skullgirls so much?!?!  Skullgirls is an interesting one. It's like any normal fighting game, but with waifus. I'm not too sure what more of an explenation you would want but I think that's a good place to start. So what makes skullgirls so amazing? Well that would be everything, which currently includes intuitive gameplay, beautiful hand drawn visuals, an increadible and catchy soundtrack, it's easy to play but is complex enough to be mastered, brief, but interesting story modes for each character, a very in depth tutorial , TONS of lore, multiple clever references to memes and other games, fanservice, flashy and awe inspireing supermoves, the big middle finger to physics, and last but certainly not least, a cast of increadibly interesting and likeable characters. Seriously there is not one character in this game that I dont like to some extent, and while you could argue that this is because the roster is rather small (8 characters normally) this is more or less because it features DLC that adds in an extra 4 characters, with more constantly being made. Sooo yeah, Skullgirls. It's a great game with great developers, and a great fanbase. And it's only 15$, what more could you ask for? An outstanding 9/10 in my book.

reviewText:
Wonderful and colorful fanserviceable fightie.

I'm not the best at Guilty Gear style fighting games, but they're still fun and offer loads challenge. This one tops it off with gorgeous art-work, fun character design, amazing jazzy music and even some story to every one of the roster. All characters are damn well defined both in terms of story and, most important, unique game-play.

It *is* a faster type of fighting game, similar to Japanese ones, and offers loads of depth. Yet at the same remains accessible to new-comers. A nice mix of a far-going learning curve that's not as steep as you might think and of solid top-notch gameplay.

Roster's a bit small at the moment tho...

reviewText: One of my favorite 2-D fighters with well done, hand drawn characters and animations. The rooster consists of (at the moment) an all female cast that are unique fighters in their own way. No one character feels like a clone of each other and has a very distinct, over the top fighting style. The best feature of this game by far is the in game tutorial which teaches the player literally EVERYTHING about the game mechanics and character abilities. I have not seen a tutorial that thorough since DBZBT3 for the ps2. The combat is very fluid and responsive and as far as I can tell all the characters feel balanced. There isn't one overpowered character that just gets mained for the sake of winning ( looking at you UMVC3 cough wesker cough) so its entirely possible to play competitively with your favorite character ( my case squigly, fillia and peacock). I recommend it for anyone looking for a new fighter game or new players who want to learn general fighting game mechanics.  8/10.

reviewText:
-General-
Not for the prudes or someone that doesn't have a computer gaming controller. There's alot of boobs that will be flying around in your face regularly. Big bouncy boobs. And playing this with a keyboard is very frustrating and fills you with a sense of it not being worthwhile to try.

-Combat-
The fighting is what you'd expect from any 2d arena fighter, maybe being a little bit more faster pace than KoF or Mortal Kombat. Super attacks, combo resets, etc. Some characters excel in a particular style like Parasoul and Peacock being very annoying rangers, or Squigly and Fortune being good at chaining and resetting combos, or disrupting their opponents. But i dont feel as though their is a reliable blocking system personally.

-Art & Music-
The art style i must say is absolutely stellar. It's really something that you would love to see as a full fledged tv series. The music I dont feel is too outstanding and gets repetitive rather quickly, but its still good, i find myself humming some tunes from the game now and then.

-Story-
Each character has their own story and every story is it's own story for that particular character. The foundation is the same in that the Skullgirl focus and final boss, with a pair of designated recurring antagonists, but that aside, every character's story is non-canon to anothers with maybe one or two overlapping continuities. [X] will kill [Y] in [X]'s story, but [Y]'s story has little to do with [X]. Some stories are more interesting than others. Not saying thats a bad thing, thats just how it goes.

-Verdict-
6.5 Now i give it a middle score not because i think its not a good game. I think its a great game but not too outstanding aside from its artstyle and i am a sucker for beautiful detailed artwork. It's definitely unique with its universe and its certainly worth a try.

reviewText:
Caution: The Words and Descriptions used by DrKrazy are probably mispelled and in poor grammar and may not reflect the opinions of other gamers.

Skull Girls: Encore

Intro:
With 2D fighting hitting a slump for me in the early 2000's It was either Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat, or Guilty Gear. Original 2D Fighting Games were hard to come by. And Announced Late 2011 Skullgirls was being developed. And in Late Spring 2012 Skullgirls arrived with art from ~Oh8~ [Alex Ahad] and Street Fighter Vetran [Mike Zaimont]. With a fresh art style and a someone familiar with the pros and cons of 2D fighter of the past, I have good feels about this game.

Gameplay:
The launch in 2012 was fantastic but with Mike Z" at the helm the game is constantly evolving. And if you're part of the Beta on Steam the power is in your hands. The infamous 6-button layout returns in the Indie Fighter with 3 punches and 3 kicks. Each button with various damage and speeds. Did you like the 3 vs 3 with the Versus series from Capcom? Think you're badass 3 vs 1? You can with this title!! With very responsive controls and easy to pick up layout you'll be mashing away with your friends until you learn those special moves. Speaking of special moves
date:
The creators have poured there hearts and souls into their training mode. From AI controlled comupters to programable dummies. The gameplay feels wonderful and the visuals are a breath of fresh air compared to the other titles you've been juggling since 2000.

Art/Music:
As I've said before Alex Ahad brought a new style and beautiful visuals to this title. Some characters are pretty "eww" (Looking at the character Double) but the rest are eye popping with detail and so many vivid frames. And courtasy of the Fundraising campaign
recommended:
the roster has been bumped from 8 to 14. Each character more interesting than the last. From Zombie Opra Singers to Pharroh's with Blood Magic. The character designs do nothing but amaze me everytime I play a round. And what's a great art style without a great soundtrack? Michiru Yamane and the music team gave a good blend of tunes that should increase the enjoyment of story mode and all the stages. Good feels from both Art and Music.

Accessability:
When folks see Mike "Z" as a seasoned vetran of Fighting Games some may be scared to try this game. I say "Nay!" Skullgirls has a tutorial mode to make even the novice of players be able to block like the pros. It may not happen overnight but the tutorial mode will tell you what to look for and it will even help you learn a character. Online gameplay is well thought out with GGPO and the players online are fierce with vigor. (Trust me I'm 0-12 still) But the story mode for each character is fun and well written. Speaking of characters
hoursPlayed:
since launch Skullgirls is adding a total of 6 new characters!! Add those to the original 8 and you have 14 possible character to choose from. Each with unique animations and playstyles.

Verdict:
I like this game a lot! The User feedback
voteText: the crowd-funded characters
helpfulPercent: and the evolving gameplay! I think this game should be in any 2D Fighters library! Heck
votesHelpful: gift it to a friend on the next steam sale. Because their lobby system involves everyone! No more boring "round robin" style lobbies! (Thank god!!) My only issues with the game is once their funding goes away
votesTotal:
will there be a second one? Either way this title has earned its stripes with me.

Conclusion:
Thanks for reading this lame review I typed on a whim. But I hope you consider this title when and if you're looking for that NON-Mainstream title. Because I have purchase it for 2 platforms now. And I dont regret a thing!!


~DrKrazy~"

reviewText: Alright so when I first looked at this game I wasn't exactly expecting what I got when my friend sent me a copy of it. I expected just another 2D fighting game, decent multiplayer, and lots of super-pointlessly sexualized women. That's not what I got at all! Sure three or four of the main eight were rather big-boobed and little-clothing'ed but honestly this game isn't even about that. This game's storyline is great, and if you look more into it online it only gets better. I actually cried over the ending of the DLC Character Squigly's campaign. I've never cried over a video game let alone one with a storyline it took me 30 minutes to beat. So if you're thinking about picking this up but are wondering if it's really worth it. It is. The multiplayer is fun and rather intense so it's good to play with friends. The story modes are totally replayable, and all the characters are unique and have diverse and incredibally interesting backstories. So I leave you with a good luck because the vanilla controls are really hard to get so I'd suggest re-mapping them to your perfered setup. Have fun ^_^

reviewText: I've had a great time messing around with it, and the online play was spot on when I played against a few of my local friends. It's a very traditional SF-style fighter with better movement mechanics (air dashes for example). The Tutorial Mode really helped me understand what I was doing and how the whole system of traditional 2d fighters works. It also gives you the lessons you need to pull off combos yourself, which is great for someone who used to just button mash. Overall, I will say this game is a good buy.

reviewText:
This is like a darker, more adorable version Marvel vs. Capcom -- except better. It's a fighter with great controls whether you have a gamepad or are using your computer keys (as I typically do). The characters each have their own unique gameplay and moves as well as backstories that are both incredibly depressing and incredibly clever. It's such a blast learning how to play each one, as well as learning how each character became twisted in this surprisingly dark story.

Definitely a great game to play either with friends or on your own against computers!

10/10 would recommend. (:

reviewText: Now before I get started I would like to say that I don't play that many fighting games on a competative level aside from Smash Bros. I've played games like MvC3, Ki, and Mk9, which are all good but eventually got stale to me. So why in the holy f**k do I love Skullgirls so much?!?!  Skullgirls is an interesting one. It's like any normal fighting game, but with waifus. I'm not too sure what more of an explenation you would want but I think that's a good place to start. So what makes skullgirls so amazing? Well that would be everything, which currently includes intuitive gameplay, beautiful hand drawn visuals, an increadible and catchy soundtrack, it's easy to play but is complex enough to be mastered, brief, but interesting story modes for each character, a very in depth tutorial , TONS of lore, multiple clever references to memes and other games, fanservice, flashy and awe inspireing supermoves, the big middle finger to physics, and last but certainly not least, a cast of increadibly interesting and likeable characters. Seriously there is not one character in this game that I dont like to some extent, and while you could argue that this is because the roster is rather small (8 characters normally) this is more or less because it features DLC that adds in an extra 4 characters, with more constantly being made. Sooo yeah, Skullgirls. It's a great game with great developers, and a great fanbase. And it's only 15$, what more could you ask for? An outstanding 9/10 in my book.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a team-based fighting game set in its rather original world full of colourful characters, dark stories and general weirdness.

Using general premise of games like MvC, SG has rather conservative (in terms of numbers, at least) roster of rather diverse characters with quite a bit of options. Development team constantly works on the game, regularly patching bugs and other issues and - what's, perhaps, the most important part - constantly experimenting with existing characters in BETA build every SG player has access to. New characters are added every now and then and as of now, at least two are yet to be released in addition to a dozen of existing ones. If you have the game when those are released, you'll have them for free btw.

The game can be fast and complex enough for FG veterans to feel at home, while keeping basic inputs as simple as possible. Combined with very decent tutorials, it makes SG pretty welcoming to new players, including those not very familliar with competitive fighting games (even if it's probably not the simpliest FG to become average or better at, but it's understandable given it's premise). It can be pretty fun to play casually too, and it helps that visual style, while possibly repulsive at first glance to some people, is pretty creative and occasionally funny, can be pretty decent party game.

Basic idea (teams) of the game can be describled somewhat like this:
- You pick a team of 1-3 different characters, smaller team has more HP and damage per character;
- You control one of them while you can call others to assist you or to replace your point character";
- Assist move is chosen before the game starts
date: it can be any of normal or special moves available to the character
recommended:
plus every character has one move that is used specifically when she's called to make an entrance and stay.
- Fight until only one team has someone left standing.

It's simple
hoursPlayed: but can lead to rather deep gameplay - if you choose to go there
voteText: of course!\n\nWould definitely recommend for gameplay
helpfulPercent: artstyle and for the fact that this game has developers' support that every fighting game should have in my humble opinion."

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a unique game. I never really played a fighting game on my computer, I did play some well-known fighting games on consoles, but if I had to be fair these experiences were sort of easy to forget. Skullgirls just had the charm that the other fighting games I played hadn't.

In terms of mechanics, Skullgirls is very fluid. I'm not really a good-enough player to be launching precise strikes and combos on my opponent, but I truly felt that the game had a good sense of collision, and this is hard to pull off with a 2D game. The combat also does well with its fighters; every fighter is unique and has their own unique style of fighting. You'll find that playing Peacock, as her tutorial suggests, is truly better to play with ranged attacks, while Ms. Fortune's speciality is being able to detach her head and use it to make special attacks while her body is in an entirely different location. I don't have the hang of all the fighters just yet, but I managed to beat Marie on the first try with Ms. Fortune and on the second try with Peacock on Normal difficulty, in my book I think these two characters I've gotten more familiar with. My point is, all characters are different and suit different players, which is definitely a good thing. No character plays the same, and rarely would they have similar types of attacks.

But to admit, the game caught my attention more through its characters, stories, appearances, and the blend of emotions I get to feel; one character's story is going to be full of humorous points, while the other could be just tearjerking, sometimes the two even blend into one. Interestingly enough, there's a lot of story that's hard to find out through playing the game alone, which is something I aim to expand my knowledge on past the writing of this review.

What makes Skullgirls, in my opinion, better than any fighting game I've played so far?

The combat is fluid, but at the same time it's unique. It's loose! There are a lot of various attacks (And don't get me started on how various Peacock's are), and it's playable. The game itself doesn't try to be edgy or anything, rather it has different fighters that give different sorts of feelings. Sexiness? Go for Valentine. Goofiness? Use Peacock. Adorableness? Squigly's the one for you. Anger? Painwheel. Horrible? That would be Double. There aren't many fighters just yet (As there is always potential and room for more), but that compensates for their good variability, appearance, and absolutely great voice acting.

And who could forget about the game's non-mechanical aspects? The game is very visually beautiful, it's drawn well and animated with skill, the soundtrack is something I've already put on my MP3 playlist, and the character designs make the game remarkable in that aspect.


I'll conclude by saying that as much as I lack experience, I love this game.

reviewText:
Very amusing little game that can be considered a smooth entry into the fighting genre due to its very detailed tutorial. It takes you by the hand and painstakingly teaches you everything you need to know in order to master the game. It is so simple. The level of detail that has been put into the tutorial has almost made it a little game of its own. Huge kudos to the developers for this feat. I barely consider myself a fan of the genre and to tell you the truth I did not expect much when I installed it (as part of a midweek madness limited free-play). Nonetheless, when I got to run it and take it for a test-drive, I felt that I actually liked the experience. I can safely say it was all because of the tutorial section. No excuses anymore to start mashing all the keys in order to come up with some random powerful attack/combo.

The colors are vivid and backgrounds are strongly thematic and diverse. The characters are funny, freaky or/and sexy (leggy and busty ladies with interesting attires/appendages) and the dialogues (lines really not real dialogues since most of the story is given as text) are funny as well.

Control by keyboard is responsive enough that a single player should face no problem at all. Also actions are remappable. However, since this is the classic keyboard-destroying" game genre
date: I think that a controller (or a really sturdy gaming keyboard) is more appropriate than a simple keyboard for the long run.\n\nThe concept (from a male's perspective) is also really enticing: endless catfights between powerful
recommended: cartoonish (anime style) female characters. You want to let some steam off and are tired of shooting people with shotguns and rifles? Well
hoursPlayed: this epic fight between some freaky-sexy looking women who occasionally flash their panties
voteText: is great for a change!\n\nOne thing that detracts somewhat from the gameplay are the animations that are somewhat poor. Don't get me wrong: the art and character design per se is masterful. I think that the limited number of actually drawn sprites per action has been done by design rather than accident. That said
helpfulPercent: it is my own opinion that a few more intermediate sprites would greatly contribute to a smoother and more immersive experience.\n\nAlso the base roster of contestants (disregarding DLC characters) could be somewhat richer. But I guess this is no real sin since
votesHelpful: nowadays
votesTotal: it is a generally accepted practice to provide a barebones title and enhance on it little by little over time.\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: the game "Skullgirls" was a pleasant experience and I think that if you get it at a bargain price (MIDWEEK MADNESS offer is 3€ for the basic title - without DLC) is a real must-have for any decent gamer's collection."
