reviewText:
Just discovered that you can play actual songs on Big Band trumpet, i mean, how could you not love a game with a feature like this if on top of that there is a very technical gameplay with numerous resets that rewards the knowledge of the character you're using.

Pros
-A little story mode that link up all the characters and explain their backstories
-Very technical gameplay
-Play up to 3 character in a tag kind of gamplay that can lead to different approaches of fighting
-Really nice online that don't suffers from lag a lot, played with 200-300 ping without a problem
-As far as i can tell from my experience, there is a very good community that helps newcomers
-A wide tutorial that covers up every part of skullgirl's mechaninchs except the enemy buildup meter, but that can easily be found on skullheart
-Skullheart the official skullgirls' forum, filled with: informations about every character backstory, moves, hitboxes, chains, damages, and so on, patch notes, community threads, a list of online skullgirls' streamers and a whole beginner section(also other things but it will take a lot to write down everything)
-Huge follow from the devs, with weekly patch that balances stuff out of players feedback and new character once in a while (2 new char. are in development while i'm writing down this stuff)
-New characters are free for everyone that owns the game for the first month after their release
-There is a zombie-cat-girl that throw her head like a ball, use it for combos and then play with it like a cat does with a ball of wool. She also has a Mami (the madoka magica one) palette :^)

Cons
-Requires time that you have to spend to become decent and learn how to chain different attacks of your character, then learn another one that can synergize with the one you learn before, so don't expect to just go in the multi and win costantly.
-There are people that play this game, but as far as i can tell, there are not so much so you may have some problems finding a match once in a while.
-Little roster of playing characters, at the moment there are 9 + 3 dlc char (that can be bought at 5 euros each) and other 2 that are in development
-You may need an arcade stick to fully enjoy the gameplay, but it's not really necessary as it depends a lot on the character you want to use

Final thanks to Slippery Lil' Dude that explained me a loooot of things on this game and made it more enjoyable for me c:

reviewText:
-- Skullgirls 2nd Encore Review --

// Summary //

This is my favorite fighter available on Steam at present.  All of the graphics are hand-drawn, beautiful art; all of the fighters are fine-tuned and sexy.  The developers have supported this game long after its release:  The 2nd Encore Version is a free upgrade which represents the second major free-DLC pack for the game.   Three new characters are given to the player free of charge.   Fukua, a clone of Filia, Beowulf, an unfogettable epic, and R. Fortune....a robotic Ms. Fortune.  There are also three pay-for DLC characters available.  Squigly, a host to Leviathan, Big Band, a cyborg cop with an instrument for every situation, and Eliza, ancient and divine host of Sehkmet, the Egyptian Goddess of BLOOD!  Whether you pay for the three or not, you will see them in the story, and fight them in Arcade mode.  The free-LC also comes with a slew of new stages.

// Gameplay //

Solid Marvel vs. Capcom style mayhem!  You get to choose your team in arcade and vs. mode, you can choose one super-strong hero, two strong heroes, or three normal heroes.   The game's fighting mechanics are MUCH deeper than I initially believed, and they are completely covered in the game's Training - Tutorial mode.  Are you alone against three heroes and they're switching in and out to regenerate their health?  Perform an 'Out-take' (a move that knocks the current fighter off stage and forces a new one in) and you will remove all that fighter's red health, and restore your own!

Back up against the wall while you get pounded?  Block low, and prepare to do a technical counter.  They call it something else, I forget.  Essentially, you hit two punch buttons while you block at the moment of impact and you force the opponent back, it bounces him away.  Another reviewer has complained about hit-stun recovery times being too long, allowing one hit to win the match if the fighter follows up with a good enough combo.  This is pretty untrue.  A perfect, top notch combo ended in a 'Blockbuster move' (Think Hyper, or Ultra combo) will take a third to a half of health off of you, if you're both single fighters and not teams.  Every move in this game has an adequate defense or counter.  The hit-stuns and recovery times are well calculated, and are explained in the Tutorial.  In fact, it explains that only certain moves can be cancelled into other moves before the opponent recovers.  Meaning, you can't just button mash after your poke lands.  You have to know what combos work and which ones don't.

My very favorite element so far, is that combos (called chains) are adaptable.  A combo that goes, LP, MP, MK, HP can just as easily go LP, MP, HP.  You can remove one or more moves from a chain and it still works as a chain.  Further, Standing LP, crouching MP, standing MK, crouching HP will also be a chain, if the original was true.   The combos are adaptable.  Once you know the 'rhythm' of the chain, you can adapt it to jumping, standing, or crouching.  You can edit it for when you need a shorter chain, for example; the medium kick may not be in range, and if you attempt it, and miss, the opponent may have enough time to recover from hit-stun, so you leave it out and proceed directly to the Heavy Punch.

This is a game of pokes, like a lot of fighters.  You poke until you land a hit, then you build a combo off of the poke that lands.  You don't just rush in with your heavy moves, you'll get eviscerated by an opponent that is defending waiting for you to do a move that has x frames of recovery, so that he can poke you safely, and then take off with his combo.

// Style //

No fighting game I've played has more style than this game.  I've been playing fighters since Super Street Fighter II was new.  From the music, to the announcer(s) [4 available options], the theme of showbiz, the stylized art (all of which is available in the in-game Art Gallery, plus guest art), the zany characters, the whole package.   It's never boring, and it doesn't disappoint.

Finally, it has story.  It's not like it's a novel you'll be unravelling for years, but it has a story that is compelling.  Much more compelling, in my humble opinion, than Soul Caliber or Street Fighter.  Mortal Kombat and Skullgirls are among my favorite for stories.   At least they're epic.  Save the world or change it's fate, and all that.

Fighting Shadaloo just isn't as...rewarding as taking over the world as a giant Goddess of Destruction named Sehkmet...

// Synopsis //

I imagine it will be a very long time before I get bored of Skullgirls.  Of course, I still play Marvel vs. Capcom.  This game is similar to that fighting style.

reviewText:
Skullgirls is a classic styled 2D fighting game, in the vein of Street Fighter, Guilty Gear and my personal favourite BlazBlue series, created by Lab Zero Games and published by Autumn Games and Marvelous AQL.

Gameplay:
Skullgirls works like an classic six-button arcade fighting game, but with a unique tag-battle system, which can pit different teams of one, two or three against one another
The controls feel fluid and the anti-infinite combo system, works great in preventing spammable exploits.
*Bonus*
The final boss of the story mode will be cheap as all hell to beginners.

Graphics:
This is the area where Skullgirls' artist Alex Ahad's skill shines, Every character is hand-drawn in high-resolution and with amazing smoothness in animation, this paired with beautiful 3D stage backgrounds akin to BlazBlue, makes the game look gorgeous during tense fights with lots of flashy special moves.
*Bonus*
The character designs for the female characters, may cause arousal in prebpubescent males

Story:
Skullgirls has a great but a little bit confusing storyline, which is placed into little snippets and pieces throughout the game's Story mode and is expanded upon in the DLC characters' Story modes

Music and Sounds:
This game's Soundtrack is amazing and memorable and features tracks written by Michiru Yamane (Suikoden and Castlevania), Vincent Diamante (Flower) Blaine McGurty and Brenton Kossak

Overall:
The game is one of the best fighting games made in a long while, has great art and music, and is also really cheap for what it's worth the game is also available on: PS3, XBOX360 with Encore 2 being released for PS4 and PSVita

9.0/10 It's like skyrim

reviewText:
The art style, animation, and designs are great and the music is fantastic. The characters are all play very differently, which makes choosing a character to learn fun (for a bit), but more on that in a sec. This game is fun to play with friends, however, I find that playing competetively is beyond accessible and is a minefield of infinite combos, which just makes you feel like you're really not that great, even though you beat the (really ♥♥♥♥ing hard on any difficulty that isn't easy) final boss with every character. I'm all for learning characters, hell, that's how fighting games work, but with this it just felt like that would take too long.

I recently bought Street Fighter 4 and feel that I'm already having a better time and have learnt my main (Cammy) better than I could have learnt Ms. Fortune in this by playing this game nonstop for months.

But yeah, I'll be happy to play this game with any of my friends, just don't expect to win against someone experienced, like, ever. Also, I do feel that making the free character updates paid after a month is NOT COOL though, as the roster is small without them.

However, this game does have a really nice feel that I absolutely adore, which I think is from a combination of the music, style, character/environment designs, and punchiness of it all.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
-General-
Not for the prudes or someone that doesn't have a computer gaming controller. There's alot of boobs that will be flying around in your face regularly. Big bouncy boobs. And playing this with a keyboard is very frustrating and fills you with a sense of it not being worthwhile to try.

-Combat-
The fighting is what you'd expect from any 2d arena fighter, maybe being a little bit more faster pace than KoF or Mortal Kombat. Super attacks, combo resets, etc. Some characters excel in a particular style like Parasoul and Peacock being very annoying rangers, or Squigly and Fortune being good at chaining and resetting combos, or disrupting their opponents. But i dont feel as though their is a reliable blocking system personally.

-Art & Music-
The art style i must say is absolutely stellar. It's really something that you would love to see as a full fledged tv series. The music I dont feel is too outstanding and gets repetitive rather quickly, but its still good, i find myself humming some tunes from the game now and then.

-Story-
Each character has their own story and every story is it's own story for that particular character. The foundation is the same in that the Skullgirl focus and final boss, with a pair of designated recurring antagonists, but that aside, every character's story is non-canon to anothers with maybe one or two overlapping continuities. [X] will kill [Y] in [X]'s story, but [Y]'s story has little to do with [X]. Some stories are more interesting than others. Not saying thats a bad thing, thats just how it goes.

-Verdict-
6.5 Now i give it a middle score not because i think its not a good game. I think its a great game but not too outstanding aside from its artstyle and i am a sucker for beautiful detailed artwork. It's definitely unique with its universe and its certainly worth a try.

reviewText:
For $15, this is one game you can't skimp out, even if you suck at fighting games like me.
As a standalone title, Skullgirls (Encore) is simply one of the most complete titles in the Steam library, and while a sequel/expansion (Skullgirls Second Encore, AKA Skullgirls Endless Beta) is on the way, this current edition is still quite worth picking up.
Artistically speaking, the game looks gorgeous with its steady frame rate and reportedly hand-drawn characters that are both smooth in frame transition and movement. The backgrounds and the character designs all bring in a very early 20th century look that I wholesomely appreciate. Furthermore, character designs also have plenty of references built into them, such as the most widely advertised character of Filia sporting the Japanese Futakuchi Onna".
Gameplay is also very solid. The game responds very well to button inputs

reviewText:
I've been knowing this game long time ago from ... zone. Now after I got my hands on it and finished Filla's story, I can say that this game really didn't let me down.

From my point of view, this is a great fighting game. It's not easy, it requires technique and practice. And this is a great 2D game, the graphic, the awesome music, cristal clear sound effect, I just can't see any flaws in the game design. And most importantly (about a fighting game) - it has the perfect feeling of hitting impact. This game is definitely not something that you purchased then throw away for it's bad control - the control is perfect.

If I really need to find something I'm not so satisfied about this game, is that the story mode is way too short. There are some cut scenes between fights but some of them doesn't even have any transition - I've just completed only Filia's story, and there's no cut scene, not even dialogs between the first fight with Parasoul and second fight with Cerebella - I mean, the first fight happend on the street and it was night time, the second fight happened in the day time in a park. How did I get there? If this is the story mode, then where are the stories?

9/10

reviewText:
I think this game goes well with Banana Bread so here is a recipe.
Ingredients

2-3 very ripe bananas, peeled
1/3 cup melted butter
1 cup of sugar (can easily use 3/4 cup, or drop it down to 1/2 cup if you want it less sweet)
1 egg, beaten
1 teaspoon vanilla extract
1 teaspoon baking soda
Pinch of salt
1 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour

Method

Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C), and butter a 4x8-inch loaf pan.

In a mixing bowl, mash the ripe bananas with a fork until smooth. Stir the melted butter into the mashed bananas.

Mix in the baking soda and salt. Stir in the sugar, beaten egg, and vanilla extract. Mix in the flour.

Pour the batter into your prepared loaf pan. Bake for 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes (check at 50 minutes) at 350°F (175°C), or until a tester inserted into the center comes out clean.

Remove from oven and cool completely on a rack. Remove the banana bread from the pan. Slice and serve. (A bread knife helps to make slices that aren't crumbly.)

reviewText:
One of my favorite fighting games. Every frame in the game is hand-drawn and there are a lot of frames for each character.

Speaking of characters, there are about 9, counting 12 with DLC. Doesn't seem like much, but each character has a unique set of moves, and you are able to play with up to 3 character to get insane combos. If you are looking to get a DLC character, but don't know if you will like their fighting style, then play the Endless Beta version that comes with purchasing this game. It has all the characters unlocked and even in progress stuff for future updates.

It is also a great introduction to fighting games in general, as the tutorial is really in-depth, and goes over everything you need to know, even individual characters.

The developers are very generous, as when they ever introduce a DLC character, they always make them free for a short time so you don't have to pay.

The artstyle is very appealing to me personally, as I mentioned before everything in the game is handrawn.

And the music is very impressive, it made me buy the soundtrack on Google Play.

The online has almost never any issues, as you can adjust levels for various ping of the other players, so lag is zero. Finding a game for a lower skill level may be a bit tough ( at least last time I checked ) but it helps you learn the ropes a bit to face tougher players.

_____________________________________________________________

Overall Skullgirls is a very great fighting game, with sweet music and a very appealing art style that also is good for professional players and great for beginners alike. If you are interested in fighting games or are trying to find a opening into the genre, then Skullgirls is what you are looking for.

reviewText:
Great animation. Great characters. Great gameplay. Skullgirls is my favourite 2D fighting game and one of my favourite games of all time. There are 2 main ways that the player will play this game, single player and versus.

In single player, there are three modes, story, arcade and CPU quick match. In story mode, players will select a character and play through their story. Each character has vastly different stories, so this mode is great to get new players hooked. Arcade mode is  a mode where the player will select a character or a team of characters and fight against randomly selected characters until they reach the boss. CPU quick match is pretty self-explanatory, the player selects a character or team of characters and fights against a computer opponent for one match.

In versus, players can fight against opponents from all around the world. in versus, there are a few modes to select from. Tournament will allow you to fight against many people in a tournament style fight with eliminations. In local mode, two people sitting in the same room can fight against each other. Quick match will allow you to search for a fight against one person and will only last one match. Finally, there is lobby play. In this mode players can enter a lobby with up to 9 other players. This is essentially a free-for-all with no rankings or eliminations. Players can choose to fight whoever they want and multiple fights can take place at the same time.

There is one other mode that people might play. That's the tutorial and training mode. This is the best tutorial for a fighting game I have ever seen. It is incredibly in-depth, but also simple enough for new players to understand.

reviewText:
I have previously written a review for this game but I think it's time to make a new one. My goal is to make this easy to understand at a glance.

Graphics
This one is super opinion heavy and it's best to just judge for yourself.

+ Character sprites	- The characters are all well drawn and stand out from everything on the screen. There are a ton of colors to choose from (over 20 per character) and many are references to other characters. The fanservice in this game can be seen as excessive, but I don't care about it or notice it much.
+ Stages	- The stages, for the most part, look great. The stages are somewhat 3D (which can be changed in the options) but it isn't super noticeable. They all look like they were designed with a purpose; they don't look like they were just thrown in. Another good thing about the stages is that they never distract me from the game.
+ Animation	- Everything is super well animated in this game. The attacks always look smooth and there are no animation-hitbox oddities such as the super large Street Fighter II Shoryuken hitbox.

Gameplay
+ Team size selection - Skullgirls allows you to select the number of characters are on your team. Single character teams are viable in this game because each character in a multiple character team is weakened based on the team size.
+ Overall game feel - Everything in this game feels crisp and responsive. This is personal opinion, but it is one of the best feeling fighting games I've ever played.
+ Infinite Combo Prevention System - This game has a mechanic where it detects when the opponent is doing an infinite combo and allows the other player to break free. Because of this, one combo doesn't mean a immediate loss.
+ Assist selection - When selecting your characters, you can input normals and specials as assist moves. Since these aren't new moves, you will immediately know how they work. It also provides for options that are fun to test out.

Tools for New Players
+ Great tutorial - The tutorial teaches you mechanics that are used in many other fighting games. There is also a section that teaches about each character individually.
+ Team selection makes the game easy to get into - You don't have to learn more than one character to start playing this game.
+ Great training room - Things like slow motion and showing hitboxes make it easy to understand the game's mechanics.
+ 360 Detection  - When doing a 360 motion, the game will prevent you from jumping during it.

Concluding Statements
This is one of the best fighting games I have ever played. I know that it won't be to everyone's tastes, but I find it very hard to think of places where this game is lacking. Many of the problems that people had were ironed out by the developers who continue to work on this game.  If you like games such as Marvel vs Capcom you are going to want to check this one out.  If you are new to the fighting game genre and are interested in getting better, BUY THIS GAME!  Just keep your expections high because this game is sure to surpass them.

reviewText:
Great fighting game for everyone, Its challanging at first, but when you learn a character's moves, and practise them until you can incorporate them into a combo, you feel like a super badass. Each character has different moves, different ways to do said moves, and have a different story. The characters are all memorable and well made.

The game has a large list of ingame tutorials, not just on game mechanics, etc, but also each character has a tutorial. This is one of the ONLY games where i would reccomend a controller, just because doing the combos, in my opinion, is easier using an analog stick rather than the arrow keys, although you can rebind the controls if you wanted.

I highly reccomend this game if you like fighting games like Mortal Kombat and Street Fighter. This game is great for beginners and veterans alike.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Linux port seems to have take a billion years to come out, but the end results seem just fine -- I haven't encountered any problems with this game.

So this game -- its ACTUALLY pretty damn fun! I'm not necessarily a huge fighting game person but this game is pretty easy to get into. The artwork is fun and very well done, the animiations are great, the music is quite good and interesting. The characters (unusually for a fighting game almost all female) are very cool and interesting and quite varied. The story modes are fun but kinda short and not always easy to follow necessarily. But each character has a story so... there is a lot to watch in total, I suppose.

Another thing about this game, it runs well on pretty much everything. My Zotac CI320 runs this game smoothly -- that's a super cheap-o celeron box I use to run XBMC and occasionally stream games, But this game runs great on that tiny machine.

If you like fighting games at all, get this, its a lot of fun. Especially if you are a Linux gamer -- this and Kings of Kung Fu are the only two fighters we have at the time of this review and they are wildly different styles of gameplay.

reviewText: Probalbly one of the best western 2D fighter of all time. Simply amazing. Everything about the game makes it look pretty. To sum it all up the developers took little tidbits from alot of diffrent fighting games ranging from BlazBlue to Marvel vs Capcom. Controls are nice and tight. Online can be here and there but for most part its wonderful. Versus is always fun to play with friends. The game is still coming out with new characters. Each time a new character is realeased they are free for 2-3 months so how can you go wrong with that? There is a story mode for each character and there point of view on the main quest for each of them. Storys are all unique so it not a drag to go through each one. I highly reccomend this game for people new to the fighting game community especially since the turtorial gives you a grasp on how fighting game mechanics work. Give it a go I promise you will not be dissapointed.

reviewText:
-Fantastic art style
-Technical fighting (Not as slow as MK, but not as tightly timed as KoF... similar to MvC's)
-Unique and creative character design (some notables:  A cat-lady that uses her severed head in fights, a blob of shapeshifting religious goo, and a living weapon designed weilded by a cartoon-crazed-death-machine)
-So many hours of replayability
-(1,2,3)v(1,2,3) gameplay in *any* mode (so neat) WITH fully customizeable assists
-GGPO is pretty slick (manual frame delay for online smoothness), though I would recommend not going higher than 4 frames to fight anybody, optimally at 0-1 or local play
